On sensing capacity of sensor networks for the class of linear observation, fixed SNR models

Shuchin Aeron, Manqi Zhao, and Venkatesh Saligrama The authors are with the department of Electrical and Computer Engineering at Boston University, MA -02215. They can be reached at {shuchin, mqzhao, srv}@bu.edu
Abstract

In this paper we address the problem of finding the sensing capacity of sensor networks for a class of linear observation models and a fixed SNR regime. Sensing capacity is defined as the maximum number of signal dimensions reliably identified per sensor observation. In this context sparsity of the phenomena is a key feature that determines sensing capacity. Precluding the SNR of the environment the effect of sparsity on the number of measurements required for accurate reconstruction of a sparse phenomena has been widely dealt with under compressed sensing. Nevertheless the development there was motivated from an algorithmic perspective. In this paper our aim is to derive these bounds in an information theoretic set-up and thus provide algorithm independent conditions for reliable reconstruction of sparse signals. In this direction we first generalize the Fano’s inequality and provide lower bounds to the probability of error in reconstruction subject to an arbitrary distortion criteria. Using these lower bounds to the probability of error, we derive upper bounds to sensing capacity and show that for fixed SNR regime sensing capacity goes down to zero as sparsity goes down to zero. This means that disproportionately more sensors are required to monitor very sparse events. We derive lower bounds to sensing capacity (achievable) via deriving upper bounds to the probability of error via adaptation to a max-likelihood detection set-up under a given distortion criteria. These lower bounds to sensing capacity exhibit similar behavior though there is an SNR gap in the upper and lower bounds. Subsequently, we show the effect of correlation in sensing across sensors and across sensing modalities on sensing capacity for various degrees and models of correlation. Our next main contribution is that we show the effect of sensing diversity on sensing capacity, an effect that has not been considered before. Sensing diversity is related to the effective coverage of a sensor with respect to the field. In this direction we show the following results (a) Sensing capacity goes down as sensing diversity per sensor goes down; (b) Random sampling (coverage) of the field by sensors is better than contiguous location sampling (coverage). In essence the bounds and the results presented in this paper serve as guidelines for designing efficient sensor network architectures.

I Introduction

In this paper we study fundamental limits to the performance of sensor networks for a class of linear sensing models under a fixed SNR regime. Fixed SNR is an important and necessary ingredient for sensor network applications where the observations are inevitably corrupted by external noise and clutter. In addition we are motivated by sensor network applications where the underlying phenomena exhibits sparsity. Sparsity is manifested in many applications for which sensor networks are deployed, e.g. localization of few targets in a large region, search for targets from among a large number of sites e.g. land mine detection, estimation of temperature variation for which few spline coefficients may suffice to represent the field , i.e. phenomena is sparse under a suitable transformation. More recent applications such as that considered in [1] also involve imaging a sparse scattering medium.

The motivation for considering linear sensing models comes from the fact that in most cases the observation at a sensor is a superposition of signals that emanate from different sources, locations etc. For e.g., in seismic and underground borehole sonic applications, each sensor receives signals that is a superposition of signals arriving from various point/extended sources located at different places. In radar applications [1, 2], under a far field assumption the observation system is linear and can be expressed as a matrix of steering vectors. In this case the directions becomes the variable space and one looks for strategies to optimally search using many such radars. Statistical modulation of gain factors in different directions is feasible in these scenarios and is usually done to control the statistics of backscattered data. In other scenarios the scattering medium itself induces random gain factors in different directions.

In relation to signal sparsity compressive sampling, [3, 4] has shown to be very promising in terms of acquiring minimal information, which is expressed as minimal number of random projections, that suffices for adequate reconstruction of sparse signals. Thus in this case too, the observation model is linear. In [5] this set-up was used in a sensor network application for realizing efficient sensing and information distribution system by combining with ideas from linear network coding. Also it was used in [6] to build a wireless sensor network architecture using a distributed source-channel matched communication scheme.

For applications related to wireless sensor networks where power limited sensors are deployed, it becomes necessary to compress the data at each sensor. For e.g. consider a parking surveillance system where a network of wireless low resolution cameras are deployed, [7]. With each camera taking several snapshots in space and transmitting all of them to a base station will overwhelm the wireless link to the base station. Instead transmission overhead is significantly reduced by sending a weighted sum of the observations. An illustration is shown in figure 1. A similar set-up was also considered in [8] for a robotic exploration scenario.

Motivated by the scenarios considered above we start with sensing (observation) models where at a sensor the information about the signal is acquired as a projection of the signal onto a weight vector. Under this class of observation model, the sensing model is linear and is essentially a matrix, 𝐆∈ℝm×n𝐆superscriptℝ𝑚𝑛\mathbf{G}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times n} chosen from some appropriate class particular to the application. In this work we consider a fixed S​N​R𝑆𝑁𝑅SNR model (see also [9]) where the observations at m𝑚m sensors for the signal 𝐗∈𝒳n𝐗superscript𝒳𝑛\mathbf{X}\in{\cal X}^{n} are given by,

𝐘=S​N​R​𝐆𝐗+𝐍𝐘𝑆𝑁𝑅𝐆𝐗𝐍\mathbf{Y}=\sqrt{SNR}\,\,\mathbf{G}\mathbf{X}+\mathbf{N} (1)

where each row of the matrix 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} is restricted to have a unit ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm and where 𝐍𝐍\mathbf{N} is the noise vector with unit noise power in each dimension. It is important to consider fixed SNR scenario particularly for applications related to sensor networks. Practically each sensor is power limited. In an active sensing scenario the sensors distribute this power to sense different modalities, or to look (beamform) in various directions. Thus we restrict the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm of each row of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} to be unity and then scale the system model appropriately by S​N​R𝑆𝑁𝑅SNR. For a networked setting we assume that the observations made at the sensors are available for processing at a centralized location or node. In case when this is infeasible or costly, information can be exchanged or aggregated at each sensor using distributed consensus type algorithms, such as that studied in [10].

In order utilize the information theoretic ideas and tools, we adopt a Bayesian perspective and assume a prior distribution on 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}. Another motivation for considering a Bayesian set-up is that one can potentially model classification/detection scenarios where prior information is usually available and is useful. Note that under some technical conditions it can be shown that a lower bound to the Bayesian error is also lower bound to worst case probability of error for the parametric set-up. Therefore the lower bounds presented in this paper also provide lower bounds to the parameter estimation problem.

In this paper we capture the system performance via evaluating asymptotic upper and lower bounds to the ratio C​(d0)=nm𝐶subscript𝑑0𝑛𝑚C(d_{0})=\frac{n}{m} such that reconstruction to within a distortion level d0subscript𝑑0d_{0} is feasible. We call the ratio C​(d0)𝐶subscript𝑑0C(d_{0}) as sensing capacity : the number of signal dimensions reliably identified per projection (sensor). This term was coined in [11] in the context of sensor networks for discrete applications. Alternatively, bounds to C​(d0)𝐶subscript𝑑0C(d_{0}) can be interpreted as providing scaling laws for the minimal number of sensors/projections required for reliable monitoring/signal reconstruction.

For a signal sparsity level of k𝑘k, a different ratio of km𝑘𝑚\frac{k}{m} also seems to be a reasonable choice, but in most cases k𝑘k is unknown and needs to be determined, e.g., target density, or sparsest signal reconstruction. Here it is important to penalize false alarms, misclassification costs. Furthermore, n𝑛n and m𝑚m are known and part of the problem specification, while signal complexity is governed by k𝑘k, and one of our goals is to understand performance as a function of signal complexity. In this paper we show that sensing capacity C​(d0)𝐶subscript𝑑0C(d_{0}) is also a function of signal sparsity apart from S​N​R𝑆𝑁𝑅SNR.

The upper bounds to C​(d0)𝐶subscript𝑑0C(d_{0}) are derived via finding lower bounds to the probability of error in reconstruction subject to a distortion criteria, that apply to any algorithm used for reconstruction. The achievable (lower) bounds to C​(d0)𝐶subscript𝑑0C(d_{0}) are derived via upper bounding the probability of error in a max-likelihood detection set-up over the set of rate distortion quantization points. Since most of the development for these classes of problems has been algorithmic, [3, 9], our motivation for the above development is driven by the need to find fundamental algorithm independent bounds for these classes of problems. In particular, under an i.i.d model on the components of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} that models a priori information, e.g. sparsity of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}, and letting 𝐗^​(𝐘)^𝐗𝐘\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y}) denote the reconstruction of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} from 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y}, then we show that,

P​r​(1n​d​(𝐗^​(𝐘),𝐗)≥d0)≥RX​(d0)−K​(d0,n)−1n​I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)RX​(d0)−o​(1)𝑃𝑟1𝑛𝑑^𝐗𝐘𝐗subscript𝑑0subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝐾subscript𝑑0𝑛1𝑛𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝑜1\displaystyle Pr\left(\frac{1}{n}d(\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y}),\mathbf{X})\geq d_{0}\right)\geq\dfrac{R_{X}(d_{0})-K(d_{0},n)-\frac{1}{n}I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G})}{R_{X}(d_{0})}-o(1) (2)

for some appropriate distortion measure d(.,.)d(.,.) and where RX​(d0)subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0R_{X}(d_{0}) is the corresponding scalar rate distortion function; K​(n,d0)𝐾𝑛subscript𝑑0K(n,d_{0}) is bounded by a constant and it depends on the number of neighbors of a quantization point in an optimal n−limit-from𝑛n-dimensional rate distortion mapping.

Next, we consider the effect of structure of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} on the performance. Using the result on the lower bound on the probability of error given by equation (2), a necessary condition is immediately identified in order that the reconstruction to within an average distortion level d0subscript𝑑0d_{0} is feasible, which is, RX​(d0)−K​(n,d0)≤1n​I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝐾𝑛subscript𝑑01𝑛𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆R_{X}(d_{0})-K(n,d_{0})\leq\dfrac{1}{n}I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G}). For a fixed prior on 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} the performance is then determined by the mutual information term that in turn depends on 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}. This motivates us to consider the effect of the structure of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} on the performance and via evaluation of I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G}) for various ensembles of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} we quantify the performance of many different scenarios that restrict the choice of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} for sensing. Under the case when 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} is chosen independently of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} and randomly from an ensemble of matrices (to be specified later in the problem set-up), we have

I​(𝐗;𝐘,𝐆)𝐼𝐗𝐘𝐆\displaystyle I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y},\mathbf{G}) =\displaystyle= I​(𝐗;𝐆)⏟=0+I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)absent0⏟𝐼𝐗𝐆𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆\displaystyle\underset{=0}{\underbrace{I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{G})}}+I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G}) (3)
=\displaystyle= I​(𝐗;𝐘)+I​(𝐗;𝐆|𝐘)𝐼𝐗𝐘𝐼𝐗conditional𝐆𝐘\displaystyle I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y})+I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{G}|\mathbf{Y}) (4)
⇒I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)⇒absent𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆\displaystyle\Rightarrow I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G}) =\displaystyle= I​(𝐗;𝐘)+I​(𝐗;𝐆|𝐘)𝐼𝐗𝐘𝐼𝐗conditional𝐆𝐘\displaystyle I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y})+I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{G}|\mathbf{Y}) (5)

This way of expanding allow us to isolate the effect of structure of the sensing matrix 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} on the performance which in principle influences bounds on C​(d0)𝐶subscript𝑑0C(d_{0}) through the change in mutual information as captured via the equations 3-5 and as applied to satisfy the necessary conditions prescribed by the lower bound in equation (2).

Using the above idea, in this paper we will show the effect of sensing diversity on the performance, a concept which is explained next. Under the sensing model as prescribed above, at each sensor one can relate each component of the corresponding projection vector as contributing towards diversity in sensing. The total number of non-zero components in the projection vector is called sensing diversity. This terminology is analogous to that used in MIMO systems in the context of communications. As will be shown later on that loss in sensing capacity is not very significant at reasonable levels of sensing diversity (with randomization in sampling per sensor). In fact there is a saturation effect that comes into play, which implies that most of the gains can be obtained at diversity factor close to 0.50.50.5. Now if one considers the noiseless case, i.e. 𝐘=𝐆𝐗𝐘𝐆𝐗\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{G}\mathbf{X}, then it was shown in [3] that for some m𝑚m and for some sparsity k𝑘k as a function of n𝑛n and the coherence of the sensing matrix, an ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} optimization problem :

min​‖𝐗‖1subject to:𝐘=𝐆𝐗,𝐗≥0subscriptnorm𝐗1:subject toformulae-sequence𝐘𝐆𝐗𝐗0\begin{array}[]{l}\min||\mathbf{X}||_{1}\\ \mbox{subject to}:\,\,\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{G}\mathbf{X},\,\,\mathbf{X}\geq 0\end{array}

yields exact solution. To this end note that if 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} is sparse then solving the above system is computationally faster as is shown in [12].

There are other types of modalities that arise in the context of resource constrained sensor networks. As an example consider the application in [7] where each camera may be physically restricted to sample contiguous locations in space or under limited memory it is restricted to sample few locations, possibly at random. This motivates us to consider other structures on 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} under such modalities of operation. In this paper we will contrast random sampling and contiguous sampling and show that random sampling is better than contiguous sampling. In such scenarios it becomes important to address a coverage question and in some cases may lead to a poor performance. In highly resource constrained scenarios randomization in elements of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} is not feasible. In this direction we also consider an ensemble of {0,1}01\left\{0,1\right\} matrices, with and without randomization in the locations of non-zero entries in each row. To facilitate the reading of the paper we itemize the organization as follows.

  • 1.

    We present the problem set-up in section II where we make precise the signal models and the ensembles of sensing matrices that will be considered in relation to different sensor networking scenarios.

  • 2.

    In section III we will present the lower bounds to the probability of error in reconstruction subject to an average distortion criteria. The development is fairly general and is self-contained.

  • 3.

    In section IV we will present a constructive upper bound to the probability of error in reconstruction subject to an average ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} distortion criteria. The development there is particular to the fixed SNR linear sensing model that is the subject of the present paper, though the ideas are in general applicable to other sensing models and to other classes of distortion measures.

  • 4.

    Once we establish the upper and lower bounds, we will use the results to obtain upper and lower bounds to sensing capacity for the fixed SNR linear sensing models, in sections V and VI. In these sections we will consider the full diversity Gaussian ensemble for sensing matrix. The motivation to consider this model is that the mutual information and moment generating functions are easier to evaluate for the Gaussian ensemble. This is thus useful to gain initial insights into the tradeoffs of signal sparsity and SNR.

  • 5.

    Since the bounds to sensing capacity can be interpreted as providing bounds for number of projections/sensors for reliable monitoring, in section VII we will compare the scaling implied by bounds to sensing capacity to that obtained in [9] in the context of complexity penalized regularization framework.

  • 6.

    In section VIII we consider the effect of the structure of the sensing matrix 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} on sensing capacity. The section is divided into several subsections. We begin by considering the effect of sensing diversity on sensing capacity. Following that we consider the effect of correlation in the columns of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} on achievable sensing capacity. Then we consider a very general case of a deterministic sensing matrix and via upper bounding the mutual information we comment on the performance of various types of sensing architectures of interest.

  • 7.

    In section IX we consider the {0,1}01\left\{0,1\right\} ensemble for sensing matrices and provide upper bounds to sensing capacity for various modalities in sensing.

  • 8.

    In section X we give an example of how our methods can be extended to handle cases when one is interested in reconstruction of functions of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} rather than 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} itself. In this direction we will consider the case of recovery of sign patterns of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}.

II Problem Set-up

Assume that the underlying signal 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} lies in an n-dimensional space 𝒳nsuperscript𝒳𝑛{\cal X}^{n}, where 𝒳𝒳{\cal X} can be discrete or continuous. Discrete 𝒳𝒳{\cal X} models scenarios of detection or classification and continuous 𝒳𝒳{\cal X} models scenarios of estimation.

Fixed SNR model

: The observation model for the sensors is a linear observation model and is given by,

𝐘=S​N​R​𝐆𝐗+𝐍𝐘𝑆𝑁𝑅𝐆𝐗𝐍\displaystyle\mathbf{Y}=\sqrt{SNR}\,\,\mathbf{G}\mathbf{X}+\mathbf{N} (6)

which is the fixed S​N​R𝑆𝑁𝑅SNR model as described in the introduction. The matrix 𝐆∈ℝm×n𝐆superscriptℝ𝑚𝑛\mathbf{G}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times n} is a random matrix selected from an ensemble which we will state subsequently. For all m,n𝑚𝑛m,n each row of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} is restricted to have a unit ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm. The noise vector 𝐍𝐍\mathbf{N} is i.i.d. Gaussian unit variance in each dimension.

II-A Discussion about fixed SNR model

At this point it is important to bring out an important distinction of the assumption and subsequently analysis of a fixed SNR model in contrast to similar scenarios considered but in albeit high SNR setting. The observation model of equation 1 studied in this paper is related to a class of problems that have been central in statistics. In particular it is related to the problem of regression for model order selection. In this context the subsets of columns of the sensing matrix 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} form a model for signal representation which needs to be estimated from the given set of observations. The nature selects this subset in a weighted/non-weighted way as modeled by 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}. The task is then to estimate this model order and thus 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}. In other words estimate of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} in most cases is also linked to the estimate of the model order under some mild assumptions on 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}. Several representative papers in this direction are [13, 14, 15] that consider the performance of several (signal) complexity penalized estimators in both parametric and non-parametric framework. One of the key differences to note here is that the analysis of these algorithms is done for the case when S​N​R→∞→𝑆𝑁𝑅SNR\rightarrow\infty, i.e. in the limit of high SNR which is reflected by taking the additive noise variance to go to zero or not considering the noise at all. However SNR is an important and necessary ingredient for applications related to sensor networks and therefore we will not pursue a high SNR development here. Nevertheless the results obtained are directly applicable to such scenarios.

In the next section we will first outline prior distribution(s) on 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}, that reflect the sparsity of the signal 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} and the model for realizing sensing diversity in the sensing matrix 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}. Then we will outline the choices of ensembles for the sensing matrix 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}. In the following 𝒩​(m,σ2)𝒩𝑚superscript𝜎2{\cal N}(m,\sigma^{2}) denotes the Gaussian distribution with mean m𝑚m and variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}.

II-B Generative models of signal sparsity and sensing diversity

Signal sparsity

In a Bayesian set-up we model the sparsity of the phenomena by assuming a mixture distribution on the signals 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}. In particular the n𝑛n dimensional vector 𝐗=X1,…,Xn𝐗subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛\mathbf{X}=X_{1},...,X_{n} is a sequence drawn i.i.d from a mixture distribution

PX=α​𝒩​(m1,σ12)+(1−α)​𝒩​(m0,σ02)subscript𝑃𝑋𝛼𝒩subscript𝑚1superscriptsubscript𝜎121𝛼𝒩subscript𝑚0superscriptsubscript𝜎02P_{X}=\alpha{\cal N}(m_{1},\sigma_{1}^{2})+(1-\alpha){\cal N}(m_{0},\sigma_{0}^{2})

where α≤12𝛼12\alpha\leq\frac{1}{2}. In this paper we consider two cases.

  1. 1.

    Discrete Case: m1=1subscript𝑚11m_{1}=1 and m0=0subscript𝑚00m_{0}=0 and σ1=σ0=0subscript𝜎1subscript𝜎00\sigma_{1}=\sigma_{0}=0. This means that 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} is a Bernoulli(α)𝛼(\alpha) sequence. This models the discrete case for addressing problems of target localization, search, etc.

  2. 2.

    Continuous Case: m1=m2=0subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚20m_{1}=m_{2}=0 but σ12=1superscriptsubscript𝜎121\sigma_{1}^{2}=1 and σ02=0superscriptsubscript𝜎020\sigma_{0}^{2}=0. This models the continuous case.

In this context we call α𝛼\alpha the sparsity ratio which is held fixed for all values of n𝑛n. Under the above model, on an average the signal will be k𝑘k sparse where k=α​n𝑘𝛼𝑛k=\alpha n. Note that k→∞→𝑘k\rightarrow\infty as n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty.

Sensing diversity and ensemble for 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}

We consider three cases:

  1. 1.

    Gaussian ensemble: m1=m0=0subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚00m_{1}=m_{0}=0 and σ1=1;σ0=0formulae-sequencesubscript𝜎11subscript𝜎00\sigma_{1}=1;\sigma_{0}=0

  2. 2.

    Deterministic 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}: The matrix 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} is deterministic.

  3. 3.

    {0,1}m×nsuperscript01𝑚𝑛\left\{0,1\right\}^{m\times n} ensemble: m1=1;m0=0formulae-sequencesubscript𝑚11subscript𝑚00m_{1}=1;m_{0}=0 and σ1=σ0=0subscript𝜎1subscript𝜎00\sigma_{1}=\sigma_{0}=0.

The matrix is then normalized so that each row has a unit ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm. In this context we call β𝛽\beta as the (sensing) diversity ratio. Under the above model, on an average each sensor will have a diversity of l=β​n𝑙𝛽𝑛l=\beta n. Note that l→∞→𝑙l\rightarrow\infty as n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty. Given the set-up as described above the problem is to find upper and lower bounds to

C​(d0)=lim sup{nm:P​r​(1n​d​(𝐗^​(𝐘),𝐗)>d0)→0}𝐶subscript𝑑0limit-supremumconditional-set𝑛𝑚→𝑃𝑟1𝑛𝑑^𝐗𝐘𝐗subscript𝑑00C(d_{0})=\limsup\left\{\frac{n}{m}:Pr\left(\frac{1}{n}d(\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y}),\mathbf{X})>d_{0}\right)\rightarrow 0\right\}

where 𝐗^​(𝐘)^𝐗𝐘\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y}) is the reconstruction of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} from observation 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y} and where d(𝐗,𝐗^(𝐘)=∑i=1nd(Xi,X^i(𝐘))d(\mathbf{X},\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y})=\sum_{i=1}^{n}d(X_{i},\hat{X}_{i}(\mathbf{Y})) for some distortion measure d(.,.)d(.,.) defined on 𝒳×𝒳𝒳𝒳{\cal X}\times{\cal X}. In this paper we will consider Hamming distortion measure for discrete 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} and squared distortion measure for the continuous 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}. Under this set-up we exhibit the following main results:

  1. 1.

    Sensing capacity C​(d0)𝐶subscript𝑑0C(d_{0}) is also a function of S​N​R𝑆𝑁𝑅SNR, signal sparsity and sensing diversity.

  2. 2.

    For a fixed SNR sensing capacity goes to zero as sparsity goes to zero.

  3. 3.

    Low diversity implies low sensing capacity.

  4. 4.

    Correlations across the columns and across the rows of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} leads to decrease in sensing capacity.

  5. 5.

    For the {0,1}01\left\{0,1\right\} ensemble for sensing matrices, sensing capacity for random sampling is higher than for contiguous sampling.

In the next section we will provide asymptotic lower bounds on the probability of error in reconstruction subject to a distortion criteria. Following that we will provide a constructive upper bound to the probability of error. We will then use these results to evaluate upper and lower bounds to sensing capacity. In the following we will use 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} and Xnsuperscript𝑋𝑛X^{n} interchangeably.

III Bounds to the performance of estimation algorithms: lower bounds

Lemma III.1

Given observation(s) 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y} for the sequence Xn≜{X1,…,Xn}≜superscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛X^{n}\triangleq\left\{X_{1},...,X_{n}\right\} of random variables drawn i.i.d. according to PXsubscript𝑃𝑋P_{X}. Let X^n​(𝐘)superscript^𝑋𝑛𝐘\hat{X}^{n}(\mathbf{Y}) be the reconstruction of Xnsuperscript𝑋𝑛X^{n} from 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y}. Also is given a distortion measure d​(Xn,X^n​(𝐘))=∑i=1nd​(Xi,X^i​(𝐘))𝑑superscript𝑋𝑛superscript^𝑋𝑛𝐘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑑subscript𝑋𝑖subscript^𝑋𝑖𝐘d(X^{n},\hat{X}^{n}(\mathbf{Y}))=\sum_{i=1}^{n}d(X_{i},\hat{X}_{i}(\mathbf{Y})) then,

P​r​(1n​d​(X^n​(𝐘),Xn)≥d0)≥RX​(d0)−K​(d0,n)−1n​I​(Xn;𝐘)RX​(d0)−o​(1)𝑃𝑟1𝑛𝑑superscript^𝑋𝑛𝐘superscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝑑0subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝐾subscript𝑑0𝑛1𝑛𝐼superscript𝑋𝑛𝐘subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝑜1\begin{array}[]{l}Pr\left(\frac{1}{n}d(\hat{X}^{n}(\mathbf{Y}),X^{n})\geq d_{0}\right)\geq\dfrac{R_{X}(d_{0})-K(d_{0},n)-\frac{1}{n}I(X^{n};\mathbf{Y})}{R_{X}(d_{0})}-o(1)\end{array}

where K​(d0,n)𝐾subscript𝑑0𝑛K(d_{0},n) is bounded by a constant and where RX​(d0)subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0R_{X}(d_{0}) is the corresponding (scalar) rate distortion function for X𝑋X.

Proof:

See Appendix. ∎

Essentially, K(n,d0)=1n×log(♯K(n,d_{0})=\frac{1}{n}\times\log(\sharp neighbors of a quantization point in an optimal n-dimensional rate-distortion mapping). NOTE: The assumption of a scalar valued process in lemma III.1 is taken for the sake of simplicity. The results are easily generalizable and can be extended to the case of vector valued processes.

For the simpler case of discrete parameter space, the lower bound to the minimax error in a parameter estimation framework is related to the Bayesian error as follows,

min𝐗^​(𝐘)⁡max𝐗∈Θ⁡P​r​(1n​d​(𝐗,𝐗^​(Y))≥d0)subscript^𝐗𝐘subscript𝐗Θ𝑃𝑟1𝑛𝑑𝐗^𝐗𝑌subscript𝑑0\displaystyle\min_{\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y})}\max_{\mathbf{X}\in\Theta}Pr\left(\frac{1}{n}d(\mathbf{X},\hat{\mathbf{X}}(Y))\geq d_{0}\right) =\displaystyle= min𝐗^​(𝐘)⁡maxPΘ∈𝒫θ​∑𝐗∈ΘP​(𝐗)​P​r​(1n​d​(𝐗,𝐗^​(Y))≥d0)subscript^𝐗𝐘subscriptsubscript𝑃Θsubscript𝒫𝜃subscript𝐗Θ𝑃𝐗𝑃𝑟1𝑛𝑑𝐗^𝐗𝑌subscript𝑑0\displaystyle\min_{\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y})}\max_{P_{\Theta}\in{\cal P}_{\theta}}\sum_{\mathbf{X}\in\Theta}P(\mathbf{X})Pr\left(\frac{1}{n}d(\mathbf{X},\hat{\mathbf{X}}(Y))\geq d_{0}\right) (7)
≥\displaystyle\geq min𝐗^​(𝐘)​∑𝐗∈Θπ​(𝐗)​P​r​(1n​d​(𝐗,𝐗^​(Y))≥d0)subscript^𝐗𝐘subscript𝐗Θ𝜋𝐗𝑃𝑟1𝑛𝑑𝐗^𝐗𝑌subscript𝑑0\displaystyle\min_{\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y})}\sum_{\mathbf{X}\in\Theta}\pi(\mathbf{X})Pr\left(\frac{1}{n}d(\mathbf{X},\hat{\mathbf{X}}(Y))\geq d_{0}\right) (8)

where ΘΘ\Theta is the parameter space and 𝒫Θsubscript𝒫Θ{\cal P}_{\Theta} is the class of probability measures over ΘΘ\Theta and π∈𝒫𝜋𝒫\pi\in{\cal P} is any particular distribution. The above result holds true for the case of continuous parameter space under some mild technical conditions. Thus a lower bound to the probability of error as derived in this paper also puts a lower bound on the probability of error for the parametric set-up. In our set-up we will choose π𝜋\pi as a probability distribution that appropriately models the a priori information on 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}, e.g. signal sparsity. For modeling simple priors such as sparsity on 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} one can choose distributions that asymptotically put most of the mass uniformly over the relevant subset of ΘΘ\Theta and is a key ingredient in realization of the lower bound on probability of error derived in this paper.

We have the following corollary that follows from lemma III.1.

Corollary III.1

Let Xn=X1,..,XnX^{n}=X_{1},..,X_{n} be an i.i.d. sequence where each Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i} is drawn according to some distribution PX​(x)subscript𝑃𝑋𝑥P_{X}(x) and Xn∈𝒳nsuperscript𝑋𝑛superscript𝒳𝑛X^{n}\in{\cal X}^{n}, where |𝒳|𝒳|{\cal X}| is finite. Given observation 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y} about Xnsuperscript𝑋𝑛X^{n} we have,

P​r​(Xn≠X^n​(𝐘))≥H​(X)−1n​I​(Xn;𝐘)−1/nH​(X)+o​(1)−o​(1)𝑃𝑟superscript𝑋𝑛superscript^𝑋𝑛𝐘𝐻𝑋1𝑛𝐼superscript𝑋𝑛𝐘1𝑛𝐻𝑋𝑜1𝑜1Pr(X^{n}\neq\hat{X}^{n}(\mathbf{Y}))\geq\frac{H(X)-\frac{1}{n}I(X^{n};\mathbf{Y})-1/n}{H(X)+o(1)}-o(1)

III-A Tighter bounds for discrete 𝒳𝒳{\cal X} under hamming distortion

The results in the previous section can be stated for any finite n𝑛n without resorting to the use of AEP for the case of discrete alphabets, with hamming distortion as the distortion measure and for certain values of the average distortion constraint d0subscript𝑑0d_{0}. We have the following lemma.

Lemma III.2

Given observation(s) 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y} for the sequence Xn≜{X1,…,Xn}≜superscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛X^{n}\triangleq\left\{X_{1},...,X_{n}\right\} of random variables drawn i.i.d. according to PXsubscript𝑃𝑋P_{X}. Then for hamming under distortion measure dH(.,.)d_{H}(.,.), for Xi∈𝒳,|𝒳|<∞formulae-sequencesubscript𝑋𝑖𝒳𝒳X_{i}\in{\cal X},\,\,|{\cal X}|<\infty and for distortion levels, d0≤(|𝒳|−1)​minX∈𝒳⁡PXsubscript𝑑0𝒳1subscript𝑋𝒳subscript𝑃𝑋d_{0}\leq(|{\cal X}|-1)\min_{X\in{\cal X}}P_{X},

P​r​(1n​dH​(Xn,X^n​(𝐘)≥d0))≥n​RX​(d0)−I​(Xn;𝐘)−1n​log⁡(|𝒳|)−n​(h​(d0)+d0​log⁡(|𝒳|−1))𝑃𝑟1𝑛subscript𝑑𝐻superscript𝑋𝑛superscript^𝑋𝑛𝐘subscript𝑑0𝑛subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝐼superscript𝑋𝑛𝐘1𝑛𝒳𝑛ℎsubscript𝑑0subscript𝑑0𝒳1\begin{array}[]{l}Pr(\frac{1}{n}d_{H}(X^{n},\hat{X}^{n}(\mathbf{Y})\geq d_{0}))\geq\dfrac{nR_{X}(d_{0})-I(X^{n};\mathbf{Y})-1}{n\log(|{\cal X}|)-n\left(h(d_{0})+d_{0}\log(|{\cal X}|-1)\right)}\end{array}

See Appendix. ∎

III-B Comment on the proof technique

The proof of lemma III.1 closely follows the proof of Fano’s inequality [16], where we start with a distortion error event based on 1n​d​(𝐗^​(𝐘),𝐗)≥d01𝑛𝑑^𝐗𝐘𝐗subscript𝑑0\frac{1}{n}d(\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y}),\mathbf{X})\geq d_{0} and then evaluate conditional entropy of a rate-distortion mapping conditioned on the error event and the observation 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y}. To bound K​(n,d0)𝐾𝑛subscript𝑑0K(n,d_{0}), we use results in [17] for the case of squared distortion measure.

In relation to the lower bounds presented in this paper for the probability of reconstruction subject to an average distortion level one such development was considered in [18] in the context of a non-parametric regression type problem. Let θ𝜃\theta be an element of the metric space (d,Θ)𝑑Θ(d,\Theta). Then given {Yi,𝐆i}i=1msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑌𝑖subscript𝐆𝑖𝑖1𝑚\left\{Y_{i},\mathbf{G}_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{m} for some random or non-random vectors 𝐆i∈ℝnsubscript𝐆𝑖superscriptℝ𝑛\mathbf{G}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} and Yisubscript𝑌𝑖Y_{i} being the responses to these vectors under θ𝜃\theta. Also is given the set of conditional pdfs given by pθ​(𝐆i)​(Yi)subscript𝑝𝜃subscript𝐆𝑖subscript𝑌𝑖p_{\theta(\mathbf{G}_{i})}(Y_{i}) where the notation means that that the pdfs are parametrized by θ​(𝐆i)𝜃subscript𝐆𝑖\theta(\mathbf{G}_{i}). The task is to find a lower bound on the minimax reconstruction distortion under measure d𝑑d, in reconstruction of θ𝜃\theta given 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y} and 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}. In our case one can identify 𝐗≜θ≜𝐗𝜃\mathbf{X}\triangleq\theta and Θ≜𝒳n≜Θsuperscript𝒳𝑛\Theta\triangleq{\cal X}^{n} with squared metric d𝑑d. For such a set-up lower bounds on the asymptotic minimax expected distortion in reconstruction (not the probability of such an event) was derived in [18] using a variation of Fano’s bound (see [19]) under a suitable choice of worst case quantization for the parameter space Θ={space of q-smooth functions in​[0,1]n}Θspace of q-smooth functions insuperscript01𝑛\Theta=\left\{\mbox{space of q-smooth functions in}\,\,[0,1]^{n}\right\} meterized with ℓr, 1≤r≤∞subscriptℓ𝑟1𝑟\ell_{r},\,1\leq r\leq\infty distance.

Our derivation has a flavor of this method in terms of identifying the right quantization, namely the rate distortion quantization for a given level of average distortion in a Bayesian setting. Although we evaluate the lower bounds to the probability of error and not the expected distortion itself, the lower bound on the expected distortion in reconstruction follows immediately. Moreover our method works for any distortion metric d𝑑d, though in this paper we will restrict ourselves to cases of interest particular to sensor networks applications.

IV Constructive upper bound to the probability of error

In this section we will provide a constructive upper bound to the probability of error in reconstruction subject to an average squared distortion level. Unlike the lower bounds in this section we will provide upper bounds for the particular observation model of equation (6). This could potentially be generalized but we will keep our focus on the problem at hand.

To this end, given ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 and n𝑛n, assume that we are given the functional mapping f​(Xn)𝑓superscript𝑋𝑛f(X^{n}) (or f​(𝐗)𝑓𝐗f(\mathbf{X})) that corresponds to the minimal cover at average distortion level d0subscript𝑑0d_{0} as given by lemma XI.2. Upon receiving the observation 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y} the aim is to map it to the index corresponding index f​(𝐗)𝑓𝐗f(\mathbf{X}), i.e. we want to detect which distortion ball the true signal belongs to. Clearly if 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} is not typical there is an error. From lemma XI.1, the probability of this event can be bounded by an arbitrary δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 for a large enough n. So we will not worry about this a-typical event in the following.

Since all the sequences in the typical set are equiprobable, we covert the problem to a max-likelihood detection set-up over the set of rate-distortion quantization points given by the minimal cover as follows. Given 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} we and the rate distortion points corresponding to the functional mapping f​(Xn)𝑓superscript𝑋𝑛f(X^{n}), we enumerate the set of points, 𝐆​Zin∈ℝm𝐆superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑖𝑛superscriptℝ𝑚\mathbf{G}Z_{i}^{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{m}. Then given the observation 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y} we map 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y} to the nearest point (in ℝmsuperscriptℝ𝑚\mathbb{R}^{m}) 𝐆​Zin𝐆superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑖𝑛\mathbf{G}Z_{i}^{n}. Then we ask the following probability,

Pr(S​N​R𝐆f(𝐗)→S​N​R𝐆f(𝐗′)|𝐆,𝐗∈ℬi,𝐗′∈ℬj:1nds​e​t(ℬi,ℬj)≥2d0)\begin{array}[]{l}Pr\left(\sqrt{SNR}\mathbf{G}f(\mathbf{X})\rightarrow\sqrt{SNR}\mathbf{G}f(\mathbf{X}^{\prime})|\mathbf{G},\mathbf{X}\in\mathcal{B}_{i},\mathbf{X}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{B}_{j}:\frac{1}{n}d_{set}(\mathcal{B}_{i},\mathcal{B}_{j})\geq 2d_{0}\right)\par\end{array}

that is, we are asking what is the probability that the in typical max-likelihood detection set-up we will map signals from distortion ball ℬisubscriptℬ𝑖\mathcal{B}_{i} to signals in distortion ball ℬjsubscriptℬ𝑗\mathcal{B}_{j} that is at an average set distance ≥2​d0absent2subscript𝑑0\geq 2d_{0} from ℬisubscriptℬ𝑖\mathcal{B}_{i}, where ds​e​t​(ℬi,ℬj)=min𝐗∈ℬi,𝐗′∈ℬj⁡d​(𝐗,𝐗′)subscript𝑑𝑠𝑒𝑡subscriptℬ𝑖subscriptℬ𝑗subscriptformulae-sequence𝐗subscriptℬ𝑖superscript𝐗′subscriptℬ𝑗𝑑𝐗superscript𝐗′d_{set}(\mathcal{B}_{i},\mathcal{B}_{j})=\min_{\mathbf{X}\in\mathcal{B}_{i},\mathbf{X}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{B}_{j}}d(\mathbf{X},\mathbf{X}^{\prime}). For sake of brevity we denote the above probability via Pe​(p​a​i​r)subscript𝑃𝑒𝑝𝑎𝑖𝑟P_{e}(pair) to reflect it as a pairwise error probability. Since the noise is additive Gaussian noise we have

Pe(pair)=Pr(𝐍T𝐆(𝐗−𝐗′)≥12S​N​R||𝐆(𝐗−𝐗′)||2:𝐗∈ℬi,𝐗′∈ℬj)P_{e}(pair)=Pr\left(\mathbf{N}^{T}\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime})\geq\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{SNR}||\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime})||^{2}\,\,\,:\mathbf{X}\in\mathcal{B}_{i},\mathbf{X}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{B}_{j}\right)
Pe(pair)=Pr(𝐍T𝐆​(𝐗−𝐗′)‖𝐆​(𝐗−𝐗′)‖≥S​N​R2​‖𝐆​(𝐗1−𝐗2)‖||𝐆(𝐗−𝐗′)||2:𝐗∈ℬi,𝐗′∈ℬj)P_{e}(pair)=Pr\left(\mathbf{N}^{T}\frac{\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime})}{||\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime})||}\geq\frac{\sqrt{SNR}}{2||\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}_{1}-\mathbf{X}_{2})||}||\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime})||^{2}\,\,\,:\mathbf{X}\in\mathcal{B}_{i},\mathbf{X}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{B}_{j}\right)

Since noise 𝐍𝐍\mathbf{N} is AWGN noise with unit variance in each dimension, its projection onto the unit vector 𝐆​(𝐗−𝐗′)‖𝐆​(𝐗−𝐗′)‖𝐆𝐗superscript𝐗′norm𝐆𝐗superscript𝐗′\frac{\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime})}{||\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime})||} is also Gaussian with unit variance. Thus we have

Pe(pair)=Pr(N≥S​N​R2||𝐆(𝐗−𝐗′)||:𝐗∈ℬi,𝐗′∈ℬj)P_{e}(pair)=Pr\left(N\geq\frac{\sqrt{SNR}}{2}||\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime})||\,\,\,:\mathbf{X}\in\mathcal{B}_{i},\mathbf{X}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{B}_{j}\right)

By a standard approximation to the 𝒬(.){\cal Q}(.) (error) function, we have that,

Pe(f(𝐗)→f(𝐗′)|𝐗∈ℬi,𝐗′∈ℬj,𝐆:1nds​e​t(ℬi,ℬj)≥2d0)≤exp{−S​N​R​‖𝐆​(𝐗−𝐗′)‖24}P_{e}\left(f(\mathbf{X})\rightarrow f(\mathbf{X}^{\prime})|\mathbf{X}\in\mathcal{B}_{i},\mathbf{X}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{B}_{j},\mathbf{G}\,\,:\frac{1}{n}d_{set}(\mathcal{B}_{i},\mathcal{B}_{j})\geq 2d_{0}\right)\leq\exp\left\{-\dfrac{SNR||\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime})||^{2}}{4}\right\}

In the worst case we have the following bound,

Pe(f(𝐗)→f(𝐗′)|𝐗∈ℬi,𝐗′∈ℬj,𝐆:1nds​e​t(ℬi,ℬj)≥2d0)≤exp{−min𝐗∈ℬi,𝐗′∈ℬjS​N​R​‖𝐆​(𝐗−𝐗′)‖24}P_{e}\left(f(\mathbf{X})\rightarrow f(\mathbf{X}^{\prime})|\mathbf{X}\in\mathcal{B}_{i},\mathbf{X}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{B}_{j},\mathbf{G}\,\,:\frac{1}{n}d_{set}(\mathcal{B}_{i},\mathcal{B}_{j})\geq 2d_{0}\right)\leq\exp\left\{-\min_{\mathbf{X}\in\mathcal{B}_{i},\mathbf{X}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{B}_{j}}\dfrac{SNR||\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime})||^{2}}{4}\right\}

Now note that from above construction it implies that the average distortion in reconstruction of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} is bounded by 2​d02subscript𝑑02d_{0} if the distortion metric obeys triangle inequality. To evaluate the total probability of error we use the union bound to get,

P​r​(1n​d​(𝐗,𝐗^​(𝐘))≥2​d0)≤exp⁡{−min𝐗∈ℬi,𝐗′∈ℬj⁡S​N​R​‖𝐆​(𝐗−𝐗′)‖24}​2n​(RX​(d0)−K​(n,d0))𝑃𝑟1𝑛𝑑𝐗^𝐗𝐘2subscript𝑑0subscriptformulae-sequence𝐗subscriptℬ𝑖superscript𝐗′subscriptℬ𝑗𝑆𝑁𝑅superscriptnorm𝐆𝐗superscript𝐗′24superscript2𝑛subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝐾𝑛subscript𝑑0Pr\left(\frac{1}{n}d(\mathbf{X},\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y}))\geq 2d_{0}\right)\leq\exp\left\{-\min_{\mathbf{X}\in\mathcal{B}_{i},\mathbf{X}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{B}_{j}}\dfrac{SNR||\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime})||^{2}}{4}\right\}2^{n(R_{X}(d_{0})-K(n,d_{0}))}

We will use this general form and apply it to particular cases of ensembles of the sensing matrix 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}. In the following sections we begin by providing upper and lower bounds to the sensing capacity for the Gaussian ensemble for full diversity.

V Sensing Capacity: Upper bounds, Gaussian ensemble

V-A Discrete 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}, full diversity, Gaussian ensemble

For this case we have the following main lemma.

Lemma V.1

Given 𝐗∈{0,1}n𝐗superscript01𝑛\mathbf{X}\in\left\{0,1\right\}^{n} drawn Bernoulli (α,1−α)𝛼1𝛼(\alpha,1-\alpha) and 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} chosen from the Gaussian ensemble. Then, with the distortion measure as the hamming distortion, for a diversity ratio of β=1𝛽1\beta=1 and for d0≤αsubscript𝑑0𝛼d_{0}\leq\alpha, the sensing capacity C𝐶C is upper bounded by

C​(d0)≤12​log⁡(1+α​S​N​R)RX​(d0)𝐶subscript𝑑0121𝛼𝑆𝑁𝑅subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0C(d_{0})\leq\dfrac{\frac{1}{2}\log(1+\alpha SNR)}{R_{X}(d_{0})}
Proof:

From lemma III.2 the probability of error is lower bounded by zero if the numerator in the lower bound is negative, this implies for any m,n𝑚𝑛m,n that

Cm,n​(d0,𝐆)≤1m​I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)RX​(d0)subscript𝐶𝑚𝑛subscript𝑑0𝐆1𝑚𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0C_{m,n}(d_{0},\mathbf{G})\leq\dfrac{\frac{1}{m}I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G})}{R_{X}(d_{0})}

Since 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} is random we take expectation over 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}. It can be shown that the mutual information

𝐄𝐆​I​(Xn;𝐘|𝐆)≤maxP𝐗:∑1n​𝐄​Xi2≤α⁡12​𝐄𝐆​log⁡d​e​t​(𝐈m×m+𝐆𝐗𝐗T​𝐆T)subscript𝐄𝐆𝐼superscript𝑋𝑛conditional𝐘𝐆absentsubscript:subscript𝑃𝐗1𝑛𝐄superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑖2𝛼12subscript𝐄𝐆𝑑𝑒𝑡subscript𝐈𝑚𝑚superscript𝐆𝐗𝐗𝑇superscript𝐆𝑇\begin{array}[]{l}\mathbf{E}_{\mathbf{G}}I(X^{n};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G})\leq\\ \max_{P_{\mathbf{X}}:\sum\frac{1}{n}\mathbf{E}X_{i}^{2}\leq\alpha}\frac{1}{2}\mathbf{E}_{\mathbf{G}}\log det(\mathbf{I}_{m\times m}+\mathbf{G}\mathbf{X}\mathbf{X}^{T}\mathbf{G}^{T})\end{array}

=𝐄λ1,..,λm​∑i=1m12​log⁡(1+λi​α​S​N​R)=\mathbf{E}_{\lambda_{1},..,\lambda_{m}}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\frac{1}{2}\log(1+\lambda_{i}\alpha SNR) where λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} are singular values of 𝐆𝐆Tsuperscript𝐆𝐆𝑇\mathbf{G}\mathbf{G}^{T}. Since rows of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} have a unit norm ⇒λi≤1​∀i⇒absentsubscript𝜆𝑖1for-all𝑖\Rightarrow\lambda_{i}\leq 1\,\,\forall i. Hence 𝐄𝐆​I​(Xn;𝐘|𝐆)≤m2​log⁡(1+α​S​N​R)subscript𝐄𝐆𝐼superscript𝑋𝑛conditional𝐘𝐆𝑚21𝛼𝑆𝑁𝑅\mathbf{E}_{\mathbf{G}}I(X^{n};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G})\leq\frac{m}{2}\log(1+\alpha SNR). Thus the result follows. ∎

V-B Continuous 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}, full diversity, Gaussian ensemble

Lemma V.2

Given 𝐗∈ℝn𝐗superscriptℝ𝑛\mathbf{X}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} drawn i.i.d. according to PX=α​𝒩​(0,1)+(1−α)​𝒩​(0,0)subscript𝑃𝑋𝛼𝒩011𝛼𝒩00P_{X}=\alpha{\cal N}(0,1)+(1-\alpha){\cal N}(0,0) and 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} chosen from the Gaussian ensemble. Then, for squared distortion measure, for diversity ratio β=1𝛽1\beta=1 and for d0≤α2subscript𝑑0𝛼2d_{0}\leq\frac{\alpha}{2}, the sensing capacity C​(d0)𝐶subscript𝑑0C(d_{0}) obeys,

C​(d0)≤12​log⁡(1+α​S​N​R)H​(α)+α2​log⁡α2​d0𝐶subscript𝑑0121𝛼𝑆𝑁𝑅𝐻𝛼𝛼2𝛼2subscript𝑑0C(d_{0})\leq\dfrac{\frac{1}{2}\log(1+\alpha SNR)}{H(\alpha)+\frac{\alpha}{2}\log\frac{\alpha}{2d_{0}}}
Proof:

From lemma V.1 we have that 𝐄𝐆​I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)≤m2​log⁡(1+α​S​N​R)subscript𝐄𝐆𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆𝑚21𝛼𝑆𝑁𝑅\mathbf{E}_{\mathbf{G}}I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G})\leq\frac{m}{2}\log(1+\alpha SNR). In order that the probability of error be lower bounded by zero, from lemma III.1 it follows that asymptotically

nm≤𝐄𝐆​I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)RX​(d0)−K​(d0,n)𝑛𝑚subscript𝐄𝐆𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝐾subscript𝑑0𝑛\frac{n}{m}\leq\frac{\mathbf{E}_{\mathbf{G}}I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G})}{R_{X}(d_{0})-K(d_{0},n)}

It can be shown that |K​(d0,n)−log⁡2|<ϵ𝐾subscript𝑑0𝑛2italic-ϵ|K(d_{0},n)-\log 2|<\epsilon with ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon very small for large enough n𝑛n, see e.g. [17]. The lemma then follows by plugging in the results from section XI-C. ∎

It can be easily seen that as α↓0↓𝛼0\alpha\downarrow 0 the sensing capacity goes to zero. We illustrate this by plotting the upper bounds in figure 2 for the discrete case. We will revisit this phenomena in section VII in relation to the bounds derived in [5] in the context of compressed sensing.

VI Sensing Capacity: Lower bounds, Gaussian ensemble

VI-A Discrete alphabet, full diversity

The discrete 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} with hamming distortion is a special case where we can provide tighter upper bounds. The proof follows from the development in section IV and identifying that for the discrete case one can choose the discrete set of points instead of the distortion balls. We have the following lemma.

Lemma VI.1

Given 𝐗∈𝒳n𝐗superscript𝒳𝑛\mathbf{X}\in{\cal X}^{n} with |𝒳|<∞𝒳|{\cal X}|<\infty, for β=1𝛽1\beta=1 and 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} chosen from a Gaussian ensemble. Then for d0≤minx∈𝒳⁡PX​(x)subscript𝑑0subscript𝑥𝒳subscript𝑃𝑋𝑥d_{0}\leq\min_{x\in{\cal X}}P_{X}(x), a sensing capacity of

C​(d0)=12​log⁡(1+S​N​R​d02)H​(X)−d0​log⁡|𝒳−1|−d0​log⁡1d0𝐶subscript𝑑0121𝑆𝑁𝑅subscript𝑑02𝐻𝑋subscript𝑑0𝒳1subscript𝑑01subscript𝑑0C(d_{0})=\dfrac{\frac{1}{2}\log(1+\frac{SNRd_{0}}{2})}{H(X)-d_{0}\log|{\cal X}-1|-d_{0}\log\frac{1}{d_{0}}}

is achievable in that the probability of error goes down to zero exponentially for choices of C=nm=C​(d0)−η𝐶𝑛𝑚𝐶subscript𝑑0𝜂C=\frac{n}{m}=C(d_{0})-\eta for any η>0𝜂0\eta>0.

Proof:

We have

P​r​(1n​d​(𝐗,𝐗^​(𝐘))≥d0|𝐆)≤exp⁡{−S​N​R​‖𝐆​(𝐗−𝐗′)‖24}​2n​H​(X)−n​d0​log⁡|𝒳−1|−log⁡(nn​d0)𝑃𝑟1𝑛𝑑𝐗^𝐗𝐘conditionalsubscript𝑑0𝐆𝑆𝑁𝑅superscriptnorm𝐆𝐗superscript𝐗′24superscript2𝑛𝐻𝑋𝑛subscript𝑑0𝒳1binomial𝑛𝑛subscript𝑑0Pr\left(\frac{1}{n}d(\mathbf{X},\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y}))\geq d_{0}|\mathbf{G}\right)\leq\exp\left\{-\dfrac{SNR||\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime})||^{2}}{4}\right\}2^{nH(X)-nd_{0}\log|{\cal X}-1|-\log\binom{n}{nd_{0}}}

where we have applied the union bound to all the typical sequences that are outside the hamming distortion ball of radius d0subscript𝑑0d_{0}. Taking the expectation with respect to 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} we get,

P​r​(1n​d​(𝐗,𝐗^​(𝐘))≥d0)≤𝐄𝐆​exp⁡{−S​N​R​‖𝐆​(𝐗−𝐗′)‖24}​2n​H​(X)−n​d0​log⁡|𝒳−1|−log⁡(nn​d0)𝑃𝑟1𝑛𝑑𝐗^𝐗𝐘subscript𝑑0subscript𝐄𝐆𝑆𝑁𝑅superscriptnorm𝐆𝐗superscript𝐗′24superscript2𝑛𝐻𝑋𝑛subscript𝑑0𝒳1binomial𝑛𝑛subscript𝑑0Pr\left(\frac{1}{n}d(\mathbf{X},\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y}))\geq d_{0}\right)\leq\mathbf{E}_{\mathbf{G}}\exp\left\{-\dfrac{SNR||\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime})||^{2}}{4}\right\}2^{nH(X)-nd_{0}\log|{\cal X}-1|-\log\binom{n}{nd_{0}}}

Now note that since 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} is a Gaussian random matrix where each row has a unit ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm, ‖𝐆​(𝐗−𝐗′)‖2=∑i=1m|∑j=1n𝐆i​j​(Xi−Xj′)|2superscriptnorm𝐆𝐗superscript𝐗′2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛subscript𝐆𝑖𝑗subscript𝑋𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝑗2||\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime})||^{2}=\sum_{i=1}^{m}|\sum_{j=1}^{n}\mathbf{G}_{ij}(X_{i}-X^{\prime}_{j})|^{2} is a sum of m𝑚m independent χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2} random variables with mean ‖𝐗−𝐗′‖2superscriptnorm𝐗superscript𝐗′2||\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime}||^{2}. Thus from the moment generating function of the χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2} random variable we get that,

P​r​(1n​d​(𝐗,𝐗^​(𝐘))≥d0)≤(11+S​N​R​‖𝐗−𝐗′‖22​n)m/2​2n​H​(X)−n​d0​log⁡|𝒳−1|−log⁡(nn​d0)𝑃𝑟1𝑛𝑑𝐗^𝐗𝐘subscript𝑑0superscript11𝑆𝑁𝑅superscriptnorm𝐗superscript𝐗′22𝑛𝑚2superscript2𝑛𝐻𝑋𝑛subscript𝑑0𝒳1binomial𝑛𝑛subscript𝑑0Pr\left(\frac{1}{n}d(\mathbf{X},\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y}))\geq d_{0}\right)\leq\left(\dfrac{1}{1+\frac{SNR||\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime}||^{2}}{2\,n}}\right)^{m/2}2^{nH(X)-nd_{0}\log|{\cal X}-1|-\log\binom{n}{nd_{0}}}

This implies,

P​r​(1n​d​(𝐗,𝐗^​(𝐘))≥d0)≤2−m2​log⁡(1+S​N​R​d02)​2n​H​(X)−n​d0​log⁡|𝒳−1|−log⁡(nn​d0)𝑃𝑟1𝑛𝑑𝐗^𝐗𝐘subscript𝑑0superscript2𝑚21𝑆𝑁𝑅subscript𝑑02superscript2𝑛𝐻𝑋𝑛subscript𝑑0𝒳1binomial𝑛𝑛subscript𝑑0Pr\left(\frac{1}{n}d(\mathbf{X},\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y}))\geq d_{0}\right)\leq 2^{-\frac{m}{2}\log(1+\frac{SNRd_{0}}{2})}2^{nH(X)-nd_{0}\log|{\cal X}-1|-\log\binom{n}{nd_{0}}}

Now note that for d0≤αsubscript𝑑0𝛼d_{0}\leq\alpha, log⁡(nn​d0)≥n​d0​log⁡1d0binomial𝑛𝑛subscript𝑑0𝑛subscript𝑑01subscript𝑑0\log\binom{n}{nd_{0}}\geq nd_{0}\log\frac{1}{d_{0}}. Then from above one can see that the probability of error goes down to zero if,

nm<12​log⁡(1+S​N​R​d02)H​(X)−d0​log⁡|𝒳−1|−d0​log⁡1d0𝑛𝑚121𝑆𝑁𝑅subscript𝑑02𝐻𝑋subscript𝑑0𝒳1subscript𝑑01subscript𝑑0\frac{n}{m}<\dfrac{\frac{1}{2}\log(1+\frac{SNRd_{0}}{2})}{H(X)-d_{0}\log|{\cal X}-1|-d_{0}\log\frac{1}{d_{0}}}

Thus a sensing capacity of

C​(d0)=12​log⁡(1+S​N​R​d02)H​(X)−d0​log⁡|𝒳−1|−d0​log⁡1d0𝐶subscript𝑑0121𝑆𝑁𝑅subscript𝑑02𝐻𝑋subscript𝑑0𝒳1subscript𝑑01subscript𝑑0C(d_{0})=\dfrac{\frac{1}{2}\log(1+\frac{SNRd_{0}}{2})}{H(X)-d_{0}\log|{\cal X}-1|-d_{0}\log\frac{1}{d_{0}}}

is achievable in that the probability of error goes down to zero exponentially for choices of C=nm=C​(d0)−η𝐶𝑛𝑚𝐶subscript𝑑0𝜂C=\frac{n}{m}=C(d_{0})-\eta for any η>0𝜂0\eta>0.

∎

VI-B Continuous 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}, full diversity

Lemma VI.2

[Weak Achievability] For 𝐗∈ℝn𝐗superscriptℝ𝑛\mathbf{X}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} and drawn i.i.d. according to Px​(X)subscript𝑃𝑥𝑋P_{x}(X), 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} chosen from the Gaussian ensemble and β=1𝛽1\beta=1, a sensing capacity of

C​(2​d0)=12​log⁡(1+d0​S​N​R)RX​(d0)−K​(n,d0)𝐶2subscript𝑑0121subscript𝑑0𝑆𝑁𝑅subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝐾𝑛subscript𝑑0C(2d_{0})=\dfrac{\frac{1}{2}\log(1+d_{0}SNR)}{R_{X}(d_{0})-K(n,d_{0})}

is achievable in that the probability of error goes down to zero exponentially with n𝑛n for C=nm≤C​(2​d0)−ϵ𝐶𝑛𝑚𝐶2subscript𝑑0italic-ϵC=\frac{n}{m}\leq C(2d_{0})-\epsilon for some arbitrary ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0.

Proof:

For this case we invoke the construction as outlined in section IV. From the results in that section we get that,

P​r​(1n​d​(𝐗,𝐗^​(𝐘))≥2​d0)≤exp⁡{−min𝐗∈ℬi,𝐗′∈ℬj⁡S​N​R​‖𝐆​(𝐗−𝐗′)‖24}​2n​(RX​(d0)−K​(n,d0))𝑃𝑟1𝑛𝑑𝐗^𝐗𝐘2subscript𝑑0subscriptformulae-sequence𝐗subscriptℬ𝑖superscript𝐗′subscriptℬ𝑗𝑆𝑁𝑅superscriptnorm𝐆𝐗superscript𝐗′24superscript2𝑛subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝐾𝑛subscript𝑑0Pr\left(\frac{1}{n}d(\mathbf{X},\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y}))\geq 2d_{0}\right)\leq\exp\left\{-\min_{\mathbf{X}\in\mathcal{B}_{i},\mathbf{X}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{B}_{j}}\dfrac{SNR||\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime})||^{2}}{4}\right\}2^{n(R_{X}(d_{0})-K(n,d_{0}))}

Note that the result is little weaker in that guarantees are only provided to reconstruction within d0subscript𝑑0d_{0}, but one can appropriately modify the rate distortion codebook to get the desired average distortion level. Proceeding as in the case of discrete 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} and , by taking the expectation over 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} and noting that min𝐗∈ℬi,𝐗′∈ℬj​‖𝐗−𝐗′‖2≥2​n​d0subscriptformulae-sequence𝐗subscriptℬ𝑖superscript𝐗′subscriptℬ𝑗superscriptnorm𝐗superscript𝐗′22𝑛subscript𝑑0\min_{\mathbf{X}\in\mathcal{B}_{i},\mathbf{X}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{B}_{j}}||\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime}||^{2}\geq 2nd_{0}, we get that,

P​r​(1n​d​(𝐗,𝐗^​(𝐘))≥2​d0)≤(11+S​N​R​d0)m/2​2n​(RX​(d0)−K​(n,d0))𝑃𝑟1𝑛𝑑𝐗^𝐗𝐘2subscript𝑑0superscript11𝑆𝑁𝑅subscript𝑑0𝑚2superscript2𝑛subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝐾𝑛subscript𝑑0Pr\left(\frac{1}{n}d(\mathbf{X},\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y}))\geq 2d_{0}\right)\leq\left(\dfrac{1}{1+SNRd_{0}}\right)^{m/2}2^{n(R_{X}(d_{0})-K(n,d_{0}))}

This implies,

P​r​(1n​d​(𝐗,𝐗^​(𝐘))≥2​d0)≤(11+S​N​R​d0)m/2​2n​(RX​(d0)−K​(n,d0))𝑃𝑟1𝑛𝑑𝐗^𝐗𝐘2subscript𝑑0superscript11𝑆𝑁𝑅subscript𝑑0𝑚2superscript2𝑛subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝐾𝑛subscript𝑑0Pr\left(\frac{1}{n}d(\mathbf{X},\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y}))\geq 2d_{0}\right)\leq\left(\dfrac{1}{1+SNRd_{0}}\right)^{m/2}2^{n(R_{X}(d_{0})-K(n,d_{0}))}
P​r​(1n​d​(𝐗,𝐗^​(𝐘))≥2​d0)≤2−m2​log⁡(1+S​N​R​d0)​2n​(RX​(d0)−K​(n,d0))𝑃𝑟1𝑛𝑑𝐗^𝐗𝐘2subscript𝑑0superscript2𝑚21𝑆𝑁𝑅subscript𝑑0superscript2𝑛subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝐾𝑛subscript𝑑0Pr\left(\frac{1}{n}d(\mathbf{X},\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y}))\geq 2d_{0}\right)\leq 2^{-\frac{m}{2}\log(1+SNRd_{0})}2^{n(R_{X}(d_{0})-K(n,d_{0}))}

This implies that for

nm<12​log⁡(1+d0​S​N​R)RX​(d0)−K​(n,d0)𝑛𝑚121subscript𝑑0𝑆𝑁𝑅subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝐾𝑛subscript𝑑0\frac{n}{m}<\dfrac{\frac{1}{2}\log(1+d_{0}SNR)}{R_{X}(d_{0})-K(n,d_{0})}

the probability of error goes to zero exponentially. This means that a sensing capacity of

C​(2​d0)=12​log⁡(1+d0​S​N​R)RX​(d0)−K​(n,d0)𝐶2subscript𝑑0121subscript𝑑0𝑆𝑁𝑅subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝐾𝑛subscript𝑑0C(2d_{0})=\dfrac{\frac{1}{2}\log(1+d_{0}SNR)}{R_{X}(d_{0})-K(n,d_{0})}

is achievable in that the probability of error goes down to zero exponentially with n𝑛n for C=nm≤C​(d0)−η𝐶𝑛𝑚𝐶subscript𝑑0𝜂C=\frac{n}{m}\leq C(d_{0})-\eta for some arbitrary η>0𝜂0\eta>0.

∎

A plot of upper and lower bounds are shown in figure 3.

VII Comparison with existing bounds

Note that the results in this paper are stated for d0≤αsubscript𝑑0𝛼d_{0}\leq\alpha for the discrete case and for d0≤α2subscript𝑑0𝛼2d_{0}\leq\frac{\alpha}{2} for the continuous case. This is because one must consider stricter average distortion measures as the phenomena becomes sparser. To bring out this point concretely and for purposes of comparison with existing bounds, we consider the result obtained in [5] based on optimal complexity regularized estimation framework. They show that the expected mean squared error in reconstruction is upper bounded by,

𝐄​[1n​‖𝐗−𝐗^‖2]≤C1​C2​k​log⁡nm𝐄delimited-[]1𝑛superscriptnorm𝐗^𝐗2subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2𝑘𝑛𝑚\displaystyle\mathbf{E}\left[\frac{1}{n}||\mathbf{X}-\hat{\mathbf{X}}||^{2}\right]\leq C_{1}C_{2}\frac{k\log n}{m} (9)

where C1∼1similar-tosubscript𝐶11C_{1}\sim 1 and C2∼50​(P+σ)2​{(1+p)​log⁡2+4}similar-tosubscript𝐶250superscript𝑃𝜎21𝑝24C_{2}\sim 50(P+\sigma)^{2}\left\{(1+p)\log 2+4\right\}, under normalization of the signal and the noise power and p𝑝p is the number of quantization levels, [9]. To this end consider an extremely sparse case, i.e., k=1𝑘1k=1. Then the average distortion metric in equation 9, does not adequately capture the performance, as one can always declare all zeros to be the estimated vector and the distortion then is upper bounded by 𝒪​(1n)𝒪1𝑛{\cal O}(\frac{1}{n}). Consider the case when 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} is extremely sparse, i.e. α↓0↓𝛼0\alpha\downarrow 0 as 1n1𝑛\frac{1}{n}. Then a right comparison is to evaluate the average distortion per number of non-zero elements, 𝐄​[1α​n​‖𝐗−𝐗^‖2]𝐄delimited-[]1𝛼𝑛superscriptnorm𝐗^𝐗2\mathbf{E}\left[\frac{1}{\alpha n}||\mathbf{X}-\hat{\mathbf{X}}||^{2}\right]. Using this as the performance metric we have from equation 9,

𝐄​[1α​n​‖𝐗−𝐗^‖2]≤C1​C2​n​log⁡nm𝐄delimited-[]1𝛼𝑛superscriptnorm𝐗^𝐗2subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2𝑛𝑛𝑚\displaystyle\mathbf{E}\left[\frac{1}{\alpha n}||\mathbf{X}-\hat{\mathbf{X}}||^{2}\right]\leq C_{1}C_{2}\frac{n\log n}{m} (10)

When α𝛼\alpha is small then the average number of projections required such that the per non-zero element distortion is bounded by a constant, scales as 𝒪​(n​log⁡n)𝒪𝑛𝑛{\cal O}(n\log n). This is indeed consistent with our results, in that the Sensing Capacity goes down to zero as 1log⁡n1𝑛\frac{1}{\log n}.

𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} is sparse, i.e. α<1𝛼1\alpha<1 but not very small. From results on achievable sensing capacity we have that

P​r​(1n​‖𝐗−𝐗^‖2≥d0)≤−m2​log⁡(1+d0​S​N​R/2)+n​(RX​(d0)−K​(n,d0))𝑃𝑟1𝑛superscriptnorm𝐗^𝐗2subscript𝑑0𝑚21subscript𝑑0𝑆𝑁𝑅2𝑛subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝐾𝑛subscript𝑑0missing-subexpression\begin{array}[]{ll}Pr\left(\frac{1}{n}||\mathbf{X}-\hat{\mathbf{X}}||^{2}\geq d_{0}\right)\leq-\frac{m}{2}\log(1+d_{0}SNR/2)+n(R_{X}(d_{0})-K(n,d_{0}))\end{array}

In order to compare the results we fix, performance guarantee of P​r​(d​(𝐗,𝐗^)≥d0)≤ϵ𝑃𝑟𝑑𝐗^𝐗subscript𝑑0italic-ϵPr(d(\mathbf{X},\hat{\mathbf{X}})\geq d_{0})\leq\epsilon for a given ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, we have for the minimal number of projections required that,

m≥2​(log⁡(1/ϵ)+n​(RX​(d0)−K​(n,d0)))log⁡(1+d0​S​N​R/2)𝑚21italic-ϵ𝑛subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝐾𝑛subscript𝑑01subscript𝑑0𝑆𝑁𝑅2m\geq\frac{2\left(\log(1/\epsilon)+n(R_{X}(d_{0})-K(n,d_{0}))\right)}{\log(1+d_{0}SNR/2)}

from our results. From results in [9] it follows that,

m≥C1​C2​α​n​log⁡nd0​ϵ𝑚subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2𝛼𝑛𝑛subscript𝑑0italic-ϵm\geq C_{1}C_{2}\frac{\alpha n\log n}{d_{0}\epsilon}

For the special case of binary alphabet we have the following scaling orders for the number of projections in both cases, from achievable sensing capacity we have m1≥𝒪​(n​H2​(α))subscript𝑚1𝒪𝑛subscript𝐻2𝛼m_{1}\geq{\cal O}(nH_{2}(\alpha)) and from results in [9] we have m2≥𝒪​(α​n​log⁡n)subscript𝑚2𝒪𝛼𝑛𝑛m_{2}\geq{\cal O}(\alpha n\log n). A plot of these orders as a function of α𝛼\alpha for a fixed n𝑛n is shown in figure, 4.

VIII Effect of structure of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}

In this section we will show that effect of structure of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} on sensing capacity. This section is divided into several subsections and the discussion is self-contained. In section VIII-A we will show that for the Gaussian ensemble, the sensing capacity reduces for when diversity is low. Following that in section VIII-B we will show the effect of correlation across columns in the sensing matrix for the Gaussian ensemble on achievable sensing capacity. In section VIII-C we will present a general result for a generic sensing matrix 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} which will subsequently be used to highlight the effect of structures such as that induced via random filtering using a FIR filter with/without downsampling as considered in [20].

VIII-A Effect of sensing diversity, Gaussian ensemble

In order to show the effect of sensing diversity we evaluate the mutual information 𝐄𝐆​I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)subscript𝐄𝐆𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆\mathbf{E}_{\mathbf{G}}I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G}) using the intuition described in the introduction. To this end we have the following lemma.

Lemma VIII.1

For a diversity ratio of β𝛽\beta, with l=β​n𝑙𝛽𝑛l=\beta n as the average diversity per sensor and an average sparsity level of k=α​n𝑘𝛼𝑛k=\alpha n , we have

𝐄𝐆​I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)≤m2​𝐄j​[log⁡(S​N​Rl​j+1)],subscript𝐄𝐆𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆𝑚2subscript𝐄𝑗delimited-[]𝑆𝑁𝑅𝑙𝑗1\displaystyle\mathbf{E}_{\mathbf{G}}I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G})\leq\frac{m}{2}\mathbf{E}_{j}\left[\log\left(\frac{SNR}{l}j+1\right)\right], (11)

where the expectation is evaluated over the distribution

Proof:

See Appendix. ∎

In the above lemma j𝑗j plays the role of number of overlaps between the projection vector and the sparse signal. As the diversity reduces this overlap reduces and the mutual information decreases. We will illustrate this by considering the extreme case when β↓↓𝛽absent\beta\downarrow with n𝑛n as 1n1𝑛\frac{1}{n}. For this case we have,

I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)≤m2​𝐄j​[log⁡(j​S​N​Rl+1)]=m2​[(1−α)​log⁡(S​N​R⋅0+1)+α​log⁡(S​N​R+1)]=m​α2​log⁡(1+S​N​R)𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆absent𝑚2subscript𝐄𝑗delimited-[]𝑗𝑆𝑁𝑅𝑙1absent𝑚2delimited-[]1𝛼⋅𝑆𝑁𝑅01𝛼𝑆𝑁𝑅1absent𝑚𝛼21𝑆𝑁𝑅\begin{array}[]{l}I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G})\\ \leq\frac{m}{2}\mathbf{E}_{j}\left[\log\left(\frac{j\,\,SNR}{l}+1\right)\right]\\ =\frac{m}{2}[(1-\alpha)\log(SNR\cdot 0+1)+\alpha\log(SNR+1)]\\ =\frac{m\alpha}{2}\log(1+SNR)\end{array}

The effect is illustrated in figure 5. Thus low sensing diversity implies low sensing capacity.

VIII-B Effect of correlation in 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} on achievable sensing capacity

In this section we will show that correlation in sensing matrix 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} reduces achievable capacity. Correlation in 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} can arise due to many physical reasons such as correlated scattering, correlation of gains across modalities in sensing which may arise due to the physical construction of the sensor. Naturally there can be direct relations between various phenomena that can lead to such correlation. This is captured by assuming that there is correlation across the columns of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}. Consider the upper bound to the probability of error as derived in section IV,

P​r​(1n​d​(𝐗,𝐗^​(𝐘))≥2​d0)≤exp⁡{−min𝐗∈ℬi,𝐗′∈ℬj⁡S​N​R​‖𝐆​(𝐗−𝐗′)‖24}​2n​(RX​(d0)−K​(n,d0))𝑃𝑟1𝑛𝑑𝐗^𝐗𝐘2subscript𝑑0subscriptformulae-sequence𝐗subscriptℬ𝑖superscript𝐗′subscriptℬ𝑗𝑆𝑁𝑅superscriptnorm𝐆𝐗superscript𝐗′24superscript2𝑛subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝐾𝑛subscript𝑑0Pr\left(\frac{1}{n}d(\mathbf{X},\hat{\mathbf{X}}(\mathbf{Y}))\geq 2d_{0}\right)\leq\exp\left\{-\min_{\mathbf{X}\in\mathcal{B}_{i},\mathbf{X}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{B}_{j}}\dfrac{SNR||\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{X}^{\prime})||^{2}}{4}\right\}2^{n(R_{X}(d_{0})-K(n,d_{0}))}

In the above expression, the term

VIII-C Deterministic 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}

In this section we will consider deterministic matrices 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} and provide upper bounds to sensing capacity for the general case. To this end denote the rows of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} as 𝐆i,i=1, 2,…,mformulae-sequencesubscript𝐆𝑖𝑖12…𝑚\mathbf{G}_{i},\,i=1,\,2,\,\ldots,\,m. Let the cross-correlations of these rows be denoted as:

ri=𝐆iT​𝐆i+1𝐆iT​𝐆isubscript𝑟𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐆𝑖𝑇subscript𝐆𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝐆𝑖𝑇subscript𝐆𝑖r_{i}={\mathbf{G}_{i}^{T}\mathbf{G}_{i+1}\over\mathbf{G}_{i}^{T}\mathbf{G}_{i}}

Lemma VIII.2

For the generative models for the signal 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} as outlined in the problem set-up, an upper bound for the sensing capacity for a deterministic sensing matrix 𝐆∈ℝm×n𝐆superscriptℝ𝑚𝑛\mathbf{G}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times n} is given by:

C​(d0)≤∑i=1m−1log⁡(1+S​N​R​α​(1−ri)+ri​α​S​N​Rα​S​N​R+1​(1+α​S​N​R​(1−ri)))RX​(d0)−K​(n,d0)𝐶subscript𝑑0superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚11𝑆𝑁𝑅𝛼1subscript𝑟𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖𝛼𝑆𝑁𝑅𝛼𝑆𝑁𝑅11𝛼𝑆𝑁𝑅1subscript𝑟𝑖subscript𝑅𝑋subscript𝑑0𝐾𝑛subscript𝑑0C(d_{0})\leq\sum_{i=1}^{m-1}{\log\left(1+SNR\alpha(1-r_{i})+{r_{i}\alpha SNR\over\alpha SNR+1}(1+\alpha SNR(1-r_{i}))\right)\over R_{X}(d_{0})-K(n,d_{0})} (12)
Proof:

We will evaluate I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G}) via the straightforward method,

I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)=h​(𝐘|𝐆)−h​(𝐘|𝐆,𝐗)𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆ℎconditional𝐘𝐆ℎconditional𝐘𝐆𝐗I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G})=h(\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G})-h(\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G},\mathbf{X})

We will now upper bound the entropy of 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y} via,

h​(𝐘)≤h​(𝐘∗)≤h​(Y1∗)+∑i=1m−1h​(Yi+1∗∣Yi∗)≤h​(Y1∗)+h​(Yi+1∗−ηi​Yi∗)ℎ𝐘ℎsuperscript𝐘ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑌1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚1ℎconditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑌𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑖ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑌1ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑌𝑖1subscript𝜂𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑖h(\mathbf{Y})\leq h(\mathbf{Y}^{*})\leq h(Y_{1}^{*})+\sum_{i=1}^{m-1}h(Y_{i+1}^{*}\mid Y_{i}^{*})\leq h(Y_{1}^{*})+h(Y_{i+1}^{*}-\eta_{i}Y_{i}^{*})

Plugging in the quantities the result follows.

∎

Let us see the implications of the above result for one particular type of sensing matrix architecture induced via a random filtering and downsampling, considered in [20]. The output of the filter of length L<n𝐿𝑛L<n can be modeled via multiplication of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} via a Toeplitz matrix (with a banded structure). The overlap between successive rows of the matrix 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} is L−1𝐿1L-1 in this case implying a large cross correlation risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i}. From lemma 12 it follows that larger cross correlation in rows implies poor sensing capacity. Also note that for a filtering architecture one has to address a coverage issue wherein it is required that m>n−L+1𝑚𝑛𝐿1m>n-L+1. This implies that L>n−m+1𝐿𝑛𝑚1L>n-m+1. Thus the filter length has to be sufficiently large which implies that cross-correlation is also large.

Indeed randomizing each row will lead to low cross-correlation (in an expected sense) but the coverage issue still needs to be addressed. On the other hand one can subsample the output signal of length n−L+1𝑛𝐿1n-L+1 by some factor so as to reduce the cross correlation yet ensuring coverage. In this case the matrix almost becomes like a upper triangular matrix and there is a significant loss of sensing diversity. A loose tradeoff between the filter-length L𝐿L and the sampling factor d𝑑d (say) immediately follows from lemma 12 where the cross correlation changes according to ri=L​(1−d)nsubscript𝑟𝑖𝐿1𝑑𝑛r_{i}=\dfrac{L(1-d)}{n}

IX Upper bounds on Sensing Capacity for {0,1}01\left\{0,1\right\} ensemble

The main motivation for considering this ensemble comes from scenarios where randomization in the elements of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} is not feasible, e.g. field estimation from smoothed data. In this case each sensor measures a superposition of the signals that are in the sensing range of the sensor. This leads us to consider other types of modalities, e.g. contiguous sampling of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} by each sensor Vs random sampling for β<1𝛽1\beta<1. An illustration of the two types of sampling is shown in figure 6. We reveal the following contrast for the two cases for same β<1𝛽1\beta<1

Lemma IX.1

Random Sampling: For the {0,1}01\left\{0,1\right\} ensemble for sensing matrices consider the case when each row of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} has β​n𝛽𝑛\beta n ones randomly placed in n𝑛n positions. Then for discrete 𝐗∈{0,1}n𝐗superscript01𝑛\mathbf{X}\in\left\{0,1\right\}^{n} drawn Bernoulli(α)𝛼(\alpha) and for d0<αsubscript𝑑0𝛼d_{0}<\alpha,

Cr​a​n​d​(d0)≤H​(J)h2​(α)−h2​(d0)subscript𝐶𝑟𝑎𝑛𝑑subscript𝑑0𝐻𝐽subscriptℎ2𝛼subscriptℎ2subscript𝑑0C_{rand}(d_{0})\leq\frac{H(J)}{h_{2}(\alpha)-h_{2}(d_{0})}

where H(.)H(.) is the discrete entropy function and where J𝐽J is a random variable with distribution given by

Pr⁡(J=j)=(α​nj)​(n​(1−α)β​n−j)(nβ​n)Pr𝐽𝑗binomial𝛼𝑛𝑗binomial𝑛1𝛼𝛽𝑛𝑗binomial𝑛𝛽𝑛\Pr(J=j)=\dfrac{\binom{\alpha n}{j}\binom{n(1-\alpha)}{\beta n-j}}{\binom{n}{\beta n}}
Proof:

See Appendix. ∎

Lemma IX.2

Contiguous Sampling: For the {0,1}01\left\{0,1\right\} ensemble for sensing matrices consider the case where each row of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} has β​n𝛽𝑛\beta n consecutive ones randomly placed with wrap around. Then for discrete 𝐗∈{0,1}n𝐗superscript01𝑛\mathbf{X}\in\left\{0,1\right\}^{n} drawn Bernoulli(α)𝛼(\alpha) and d0<αsubscript𝑑0𝛼d_{0}<\alpha,

Cc​o​n​t​g.​(d0)≤h2​(α+β)h2​(α)−h2​(d0)subscript𝐶𝑐𝑜𝑛𝑡𝑔subscript𝑑0subscriptℎ2𝛼𝛽subscriptℎ2𝛼subscriptℎ2subscript𝑑0C_{contg.}(d_{0})\leq\frac{h_{2}(\alpha+\beta)}{h_{2}(\alpha)-h_{2}(d_{0})}
Proof:

See Appendix. ∎

As seen the upper bound, Cr​a​n​d​(d0)≥Cc​o​n​t​g.​(d0)subscript𝐶𝑟𝑎𝑛𝑑subscript𝑑0subscript𝐶𝑐𝑜𝑛𝑡𝑔subscript𝑑0C_{rand}(d_{0})\geq C_{contg.}(d_{0}). Thus randomization in 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} performs better. The difference is shown in figure 7 for a low sparsity scenario. The proofs of the lemmas IX.1 and IX.2 follow from the upper bounds to the mutual information terms as provided in section XII and then applying the necessary conditions for the lower bound on the probability of error to be lower bounded by zero.

X Estimation of functions of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}

The analysis of lower bounds to the probability of error presented in this paper extend in a straightforward way to estimation of functions of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}. In this section we will consider one such scenario that has received attention in relation to problems arising in physics. The discussion below will reveal the power of the method presented in this work and it is easily capable of handling more complicated cases and scenarios, though the computation of the terms involved in the analysis may become hard.

X-A Detecting the sign pattern of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}

Of particular interest is to estimate the sign pattern of the underlying signal 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}. To this end define a new random variable 𝐔𝐔\mathbf{U}, via

Ui={1if​Xi>0−1if​Xi<00if​Xi=0subscript𝑈𝑖cases1ifsubscript𝑋𝑖01ifsubscript𝑋𝑖00ifsubscript𝑋𝑖0U_{i}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}1&\mbox{if}\,\,X_{i}>0\\ -1&\mbox{if}\,\,X_{i}<0\\ 0&\mbox{if}\,\,X_{i}=0\end{array}\right.

The corresponding n𝑛n dimensional extension and probability distribution on 𝐔𝐔\mathbf{U} is induced directly via P𝐗subscript𝑃𝐗P_{\mathbf{X}}. In such a case note that 𝐔→𝐗→𝐘→𝐔^​(𝐘)→𝐔𝐗→𝐘→^𝐔𝐘\mathbf{U}\rightarrow\mathbf{X}\rightarrow\mathbf{Y}\rightarrow\hat{\mathbf{U}}(\mathbf{Y}) forms a Markov chain. To this end consider an error event defined via,

E={1if​𝐔≠𝐔^​(𝐘)0otherwise𝐸cases1if𝐔^𝐔𝐘0otherwiseE=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}1&\mbox{if}\,\,\mathbf{U}\neq\hat{\mathbf{U}}(\mathbf{Y})\\ 0&\mbox{otherwise}\end{array}\right.

Then we have,

H​(𝐔,E|𝐘)=H​(E|𝐘)⏟≤1+H​(𝐔|E,𝐘)=H​(𝐔|𝐘)+H​(E|𝐔,𝐘)⏟=0𝐻𝐔conditional𝐸𝐘absent1⏟𝐻conditional𝐸𝐘𝐻conditional𝐔𝐸𝐘missing-subexpression𝐻conditional𝐔𝐘absent0⏟𝐻conditional𝐸𝐔𝐘\begin{array}[]{lll}H(\mathbf{U},E|\mathbf{Y})&=&\underset{\leq 1}{\underbrace{H(E|\mathbf{Y})}}+H(\mathbf{U}|E,\mathbf{Y})\\ &=&H(\mathbf{U}|\mathbf{Y})+\underset{=0}{\underbrace{H(E|\mathbf{U},\mathbf{Y})}}\end{array}

Thus we have

XI-C Rate distortion function for the mixture Gaussian source under squared distortion measure

It has been shown in [22] that the rate distortion function for a mixture of two Gaussian sources with variances given by σ1subscript𝜎1\sigma_{1} with mixture ratio α𝛼\alpha and σ0subscript𝜎0\sigma_{0} with mixture ratio 1−α1𝛼1-\alpha, is given by

Rm​i​x​(D)={H​(α)+(1−α)2​log⁡(σ02D)+α2​log⁡(σ12D)​if​D<σ02H​(α)+α2​log⁡(α​σ12D−(1−α)​σ02)​if​σ02<D≤(1−α)​σ02+α​σ12subscript𝑅𝑚𝑖𝑥𝐷absentcases𝐻𝛼1𝛼2superscriptsubscript𝜎02𝐷𝛼2superscriptsubscript𝜎12𝐷if𝐷superscriptsubscript𝜎02𝐻𝛼𝛼2𝛼superscriptsubscript𝜎12𝐷1𝛼superscriptsubscript𝜎02ifsuperscriptsubscript𝜎02𝐷1𝛼superscriptsubscript𝜎02𝛼superscriptsubscript𝜎12\begin{array}[]{l}R_{mix}(D)=\\ \left\{\begin{array}[]{l}H(\alpha)+\frac{(1-\alpha)}{2}\log(\frac{\sigma_{0}^{2}}{D})+\frac{\alpha}{2}\log(\frac{\sigma_{1}^{2}}{D})\,\,\mbox{if}\,\,D<\sigma_{0}^{2}\\ H(\alpha)+\frac{\alpha}{2}\log(\frac{\alpha\sigma_{1}^{2}}{D-(1-\alpha)\sigma_{0}^{2}})\,\,\mbox{if}\,\,\sigma_{0}^{2}<D\leq(1-\alpha)\sigma_{0}^{2}+\alpha\sigma_{1}^{2}\end{array}\right.\end{array}

For a strict sparsity model we have σ02→0→superscriptsubscript𝜎020\sigma_{0}^{2}\rightarrow 0 we have that,
