XI-D Bounds on Mutual information

In this section we will evaluate bounds on mutual information that will be useful in characterization of the Sensing Capacity. Given that the matrix 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} is chosen independently of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} we expand the mutual information between 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} and 𝐘,𝐆𝐘𝐆\mathbf{Y},\mathbf{G} in two different ways as follows –

I​(𝐗;𝐘,𝐆)=I​(𝐗;𝐆)⏟=0+I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)=I​(𝐗;𝐘)+I​(𝐗;𝐆|𝐘)𝐼𝐗𝐘𝐆absentabsent0⏟𝐼𝐗𝐆𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆missing-subexpressionabsent𝐼𝐗𝐘𝐼𝐗conditional𝐆𝐘\begin{array}[]{ll}I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y},\mathbf{G})&=\underset{=0}{\underbrace{I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{G})}}+I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G})\\ &=I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y})+I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{G}|\mathbf{Y})\end{array}

This way of expanding gives us handle onto evaluating the mutual information with respect to the structure of the resulting sensing matrix 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}. From above we get that,

I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)=I​(𝐗;𝐘)+I​(𝐗;𝐆|𝐘)=h​(𝐘)−h​(𝐘|𝐗)+h​(𝐆|𝐘)−h​(𝐆|𝐗,𝐘)𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆absent𝐼𝐗𝐘𝐼𝐗conditional𝐆𝐘missing-subexpressionabsentℎ𝐘ℎconditional𝐘𝐗ℎconditional𝐆𝐘ℎconditional𝐆𝐗𝐘\begin{array}[]{ll}I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G})&=I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y})+I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{G}|\mathbf{Y})\\ &=h(\mathbf{Y})-h(\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{X})+h(\mathbf{G}|\mathbf{Y})-h(\mathbf{G}|\mathbf{X},\mathbf{Y})\end{array}

To this end we have the following lemma.

Lemma XI.3

For a sparsity level of α𝛼\alpha and diversity factor of β=1𝛽1\beta=1,

I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)≤m2​log⁡(1+α​PN0)𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆𝑚21𝛼𝑃subscript𝑁0I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G})\leq\frac{m}{2}\log(1+\frac{\alpha P}{N_{0}})
Proof:

First note that,

h​(𝐘)≤m2​log⁡2​π​e​(N0+α​P)ℎ𝐘𝑚22𝜋𝑒subscript𝑁0𝛼𝑃h(\mathbf{Y})\leq\frac{m}{2}\log 2\pi e(N_{0}+\alpha P)

Since conditioned on 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}, 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y} is distributed with a Gaussian density we have,

h​(𝐘|𝐗)=m2​log⁡2​π​e​(N0+∑i=1k𝐗i2​Pn)ℎconditional𝐘𝐗𝑚22𝜋𝑒subscript𝑁0superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐗𝑖2𝑃𝑛h(\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{X})=\frac{m}{2}\log 2\pi e\left(N_{0}+\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{k}\mathbf{X}_{i}^{2}P}{n}\right)
h​(𝐆|𝐘)≤h​(𝐆)=m​n2​log⁡(2​π​e​Pn)ℎconditional𝐆𝐘ℎ𝐆𝑚𝑛22𝜋𝑒𝑃𝑛h(\mathbf{G}|\mathbf{Y})\leq h(\mathbf{G})=\frac{mn}{2}\log\left(2\pi e\frac{P}{n}\right)

Note also that conditioned on 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} and 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y} the 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} has a Gaussian distribution. Now note that, h​(𝐆|𝐘,𝐗)ℎconditional𝐆𝐘𝐗h(\mathbf{G}|\mathbf{Y},\mathbf{X}). First note that, rows of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} are independent of each other given 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} and 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y}. So we can write,

h​(𝐆|𝐘,𝐗)=m​h​(𝐠𝟏|𝐘,𝐗)ℎconditional𝐆𝐘𝐗𝑚ℎconditionalsubscript𝐠1𝐘𝐗h(\mathbf{G}|\mathbf{Y},\mathbf{X})=mh(\mathbf{g_{1}}|\mathbf{Y},\mathbf{X})

where 𝐠1subscript𝐠1\mathbf{g}_{1} is the first row of the matrix 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}. Since 𝐠𝐠\mathbf{g} is Gaussian one can find the residual entropy in terms of the residual MMSE error in estimation of 𝐠𝐠\mathbf{g} given 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} and 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y}. This error is given by –

MMSE𝐠1|𝐘,𝐗=Σ𝐠1|𝐗−Σ𝐠1​𝐘|𝐗​Σ𝐘|𝐗−1​Σ𝐠1​𝐘|𝐗T=Σ𝐠1−Σ𝐠1​𝐘1|𝐗​Σ𝐘1|𝐗−1​Σ𝐠1​𝐘1|𝐗TsubscriptMMSEconditionalsubscript𝐠1𝐘𝐗absentsubscriptΣconditionalsubscript𝐠1𝐗subscriptΣconditionalsubscript𝐠1𝐘𝐗superscriptsubscriptΣconditional𝐘𝐗1superscriptsubscriptΣconditionalsubscript𝐠1𝐘𝐗𝑇missing-subexpressionabsentsubscriptΣsubscript𝐠1subscriptΣconditionalsubscript𝐠1subscript𝐘1𝐗superscriptsubscriptΣconditionalsubscript𝐘1𝐗1superscriptsubscriptΣconditionalsubscript𝐠1subscript𝐘1𝐗𝑇\begin{array}[]{ll}\mbox{MMSE}_{\mathbf{g}_{1}|\mathbf{Y},\mathbf{X}}&=\Sigma_{\mathbf{g}_{1}|\mathbf{X}}-\Sigma_{\mathbf{g}_{1}\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{X}}\Sigma_{\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{X}}^{-1}\Sigma_{\mathbf{g}_{1}\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{X}}^{T}\\ &=\Sigma_{\mathbf{g}_{1}}-\Sigma_{\mathbf{g}_{1}\mathbf{Y}_{1}|\mathbf{X}}\Sigma_{\mathbf{Y}_{1}|\mathbf{X}}^{-1}\Sigma_{\mathbf{g}_{1}\mathbf{Y}_{1}|\mathbf{X}}^{T}\end{array}

The second equation follows from the fact that 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} is independent of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} and given 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} the row 𝐠1subscript𝐠1\mathbf{g}_{1} is independent of other observations, 𝐘2,…,𝐘msubscript𝐘2…subscript𝐘𝑚\mathbf{Y}_{2},...,\mathbf{Y}_{m}. First note that given 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} we also know which positions of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} are zeros. So without lossof generality we can assume that the first k𝑘k elements of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} are non-zeros and the rest are zeros. Now note the following,

Σ𝐠1=Pn​InsubscriptΣsubscript𝐠1𝑃𝑛subscript𝐼𝑛\Sigma_{\mathbf{g}_{1}}=\frac{P}{n}I_{n}
Σ𝐠1​𝐘1|𝐗=Pn​(𝐗1⋮𝐗k𝟎n−k)subscriptΣconditionalsubscript𝐠1subscript𝐘1𝐗𝑃𝑛matrixsubscript𝐗1⋮subscript𝐗𝑘subscript0𝑛𝑘\Sigma_{\mathbf{g}_{1}\mathbf{Y}_{1}|\mathbf{X}}=\frac{P}{n}\begin{pmatrix}\mathbf{X}_{1}\\ \vdots\\ \mathbf{X}_{k}\\ \mathbf{0}_{n-k}\end{pmatrix}

where 𝟎n−ksubscript0𝑛𝑘\mathbf{0}_{n-k} is a column vector of n−k𝑛𝑘n-k zeros.

Σ𝐘1|𝐗=Pn​∑i=1k𝐗i2+N0subscriptΣconditionalsubscript𝐘1𝐗𝑃𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐗𝑖2subscript𝑁0\Sigma_{\mathbf{Y}_{1}|\mathbf{X}}=\frac{P}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{k}\mathbf{X}_{i}^{2}+N_{0}

Therefore we have,

h​(𝐠1|𝐘1,𝐗)=12log(2πe)kdet(PnIk−Pn𝐗1:kΣ𝐘1|𝐗−1Pn𝐗1:kT)+n−k2​log⁡2​π​e​Pn\begin{array}[]{l}h(\mathbf{g}_{1}|\mathbf{Y}_{1},\mathbf{X})\\ =\frac{1}{2}\log(2\pi e)^{k}\det\left(\frac{P}{n}I_{k}-\frac{P}{n}\mathbf{X}_{1:k}\Sigma_{\mathbf{Y}_{1}|\mathbf{X}}^{-1}\frac{P}{n}\mathbf{X}_{1:k}^{T}\right)\\ +\frac{n-k}{2}\log 2\pi e\frac{P}{n}\end{array}

Note that the second term on the R.H.S in the above equation corresponds to the entropy of those elements of the row 𝐠1subscript𝐠1\mathbf{g}_{1} that have no correlation with 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y}, i.e. nothing can be inferred about these elements since they overlap with zero elements of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}. Now, using the equation det(I+A​B)=det(I+B​A)𝐼𝐴𝐵𝐼𝐵𝐴\det(I+AB)=\det(I+BA), we have that

h​(𝐠1|𝐘1,𝐗)=12log(2​π​e​Pn)kdet(1−𝐗1:kTΣ𝐘1|𝐗−1Pn𝐗1:k)=12​log⁡((2​π​e​Pn)k​N0Pn​∑i=1k𝐗i2+N0)\begin{array}[]{ll}h(\mathbf{g}_{1}|\mathbf{Y}_{1},\mathbf{X})&=\frac{1}{2}\log(\frac{2\pi eP}{n})^{k}\det\left(1-\mathbf{X}_{1:k}^{T}\Sigma_{\mathbf{Y}_{1}|\mathbf{X}}^{-1}\frac{P}{n}\mathbf{X}_{1:k}\right)\\ &=\frac{1}{2}\log\left((\frac{2\pi eP}{n})^{k}\frac{N_{0}}{\frac{P}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{k}\mathbf{X}_{i}^{2}+N_{0}}\right)\end{array}

Plugging in all the expressions we get a lower bound on the mutual information I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G}) -

I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)≤m2​log⁡(1+α​PN0)𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆𝑚21𝛼𝑃subscript𝑁0I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G})\leq\frac{m}{2}\log(1+\frac{\alpha P}{N_{0}})

∎

In contrast to the upper bound derived in the proof of lemmas V.1 and V.2, this alternate derivation provides a handle to understand the effect of the structure of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} on the mutual information when one is not allowed to pick a maximizing input distribution on 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}. Moreover the above derivation can potentially handle scenarios of correlated 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}. Below we will use the above result in order to prove lemma VIII.1.

XI-E Proof of lemma VIII.1

To this end let l=β​n𝑙𝛽𝑛l=\beta n and is fixed, i.e. there are only l𝑙l non-zero terms in each row of matrix 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}. We have

h​(𝐆)=m​l2​log⁡2​π​e​Pl+m​h2​(β)ℎ𝐆𝑚𝑙22𝜋𝑒𝑃𝑙𝑚subscriptℎ2𝛽h(\mathbf{G})=\frac{ml}{2}\log 2\pi e\frac{P}{l}+mh_{2}(\beta)

Now we will first evaluate h​(𝐆|𝐘,𝐗)ℎconditional𝐆𝐘𝐗h(\mathbf{G}|\mathbf{Y},\mathbf{X}). Proceeding as in derivation of lemma XI.3, we have that,

h​(𝐆|𝐗,𝐘)=m​h​(𝐠1|𝐘1,𝐗)+m​h2​(β)ℎconditional𝐆𝐗𝐘𝑚ℎconditionalsubscript𝐠1subscript𝐘1𝐗𝑚subscriptℎ2𝛽h(\mathbf{G}|\mathbf{X},\mathbf{Y})=mh(\mathbf{g}_{1}|\mathbf{Y}_{1},\mathbf{X})+mh_{2}(\beta)

where one can see that if the matrix 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} is chosen from a Gaussian ensemble then given 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} and 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y} it tells nothing about the positions of the non-zeros in each row. Hence the additive term h2​(β)subscriptℎ2𝛽h_{2}(\beta) appears in both terms and is thus canceled in the overall calculations. So we will omit this term in the subsequent calculations. To this end, let j𝑗j denote the number of overlaps of the vector 𝐠1subscript𝐠1\mathbf{g}_{1} and the k-sparse vector 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}. Given 𝐘1subscript𝐘1\mathbf{Y}_{1} and 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} one can only infer something about those elements of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} that contribute to 𝐘1subscript𝐘1\mathbf{Y}_{1}. Given the number of overlaps j𝑗j we then have

h​(𝐠1|𝐗,𝐘1,j)=l−j2​log⁡2​π​e​Pl+12​log⁡((2​π​e​Pl)j​N0Pl​∑i=1j𝐗j2+N0)ℎconditionalsubscript𝐠1𝐗subscript𝐘1𝑗𝑙𝑗22𝜋𝑒𝑃𝑙12superscript2𝜋𝑒𝑃𝑙𝑗subscript𝑁0𝑃𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐗𝑗2subscript𝑁0\begin{array}[]{l}h(\mathbf{g}_{1}|\mathbf{X},\mathbf{Y}_{1},j)=\frac{l-j}{2}\log 2\pi e\frac{P}{l}+\frac{1}{2}\log\left((\frac{2\pi eP}{l})^{j}\frac{N_{0}}{\frac{P}{l}\sum_{i=1}^{j}\mathbf{X}_{j}^{2}+N_{0}}\right)\end{array}

where we have assumed without loss of generality that the first j𝑗j elements of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} are non-zero and overlap with elements of the first row. Now note that,

h​(𝐘|j)≤m2​log⁡2​π​e​(P​jl+N0)ℎconditional𝐘𝑗𝑚22𝜋𝑒𝑃𝑗𝑙subscript𝑁0h(\mathbf{Y}|j)\leq\frac{m}{2}\log 2\pi e(\frac{Pj}{l}+N_{0})
h​(𝐘|𝐗,j)=m2​log⁡2​π​e​(Pl​∑i=1j𝐗i2+N0)ℎconditional𝐘𝐗𝑗𝑚22𝜋𝑒𝑃𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐗𝑖2subscript𝑁0h(\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{X},j)=\frac{m}{2}\log 2\pi e\left(\frac{P}{l}\sum_{i=1}^{j}\mathbf{X}_{i}^{2}+N_{0}\right)

From above we have that,

I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆,j)=m2​log⁡(1+j​Pl​N0)𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆𝑗𝑚21𝑗𝑃𝑙subscript𝑁0I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G},j)=\frac{m}{2}\log(1+\frac{jP}{lN_{0}})

Taking the expectation with respect to the variable j𝑗j we have,

I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)=m2​𝐄j​log⁡(1+j​Pl​N0)𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆𝑚2subscript𝐄𝑗1𝑗𝑃𝑙subscript𝑁0I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G})=\frac{m}{2}\mathbf{E}_{j}\log(1+\frac{jP}{lN_{0}})

Note that j≤min⁡{k,l}𝑗𝑘𝑙j\leq\min\left\{k,l\right\} and has a distribution given by,

Pr⁡(j)=(kj)​(n−kl−j)(nl)Pr𝑗binomial𝑘𝑗binomial𝑛𝑘𝑙𝑗binomial𝑛𝑙\Pr(j)=\dfrac{\binom{k}{j}\binom{n-k}{l-j}}{\binom{n}{l}}

XII Upper bounds to Mutual information for {0,1}01\left\{0,1\right\} ensemble

In this section we will derive upper bounds to the mutual information I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G}) for the case when the matrix is chosen from a {0,1}01\left\{0,1\right\} ensemble. First it is easily seen that for this ensemble a full diversity leads to loss of rank and thus the mutual information is close to zero. So we will only consider the case β<1𝛽1\beta<1.

XII-A Random locations of 111’s in 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}

In this section we will provide simple upper bounds to the mutual information I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G}) for the case of {0,1}01\left\{0,1\right\} ensemble of sensing matrices. Note that,

I​(𝐗;𝐘|𝐆)≤I​(𝐗;𝐆𝐗|𝐆)𝐼𝐗conditional𝐘𝐆𝐼𝐗conditional𝐆𝐗𝐆I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{G})\leq I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{G}\mathbf{X}|\mathbf{G})

Let 𝐘~=𝐆𝐗~𝐘𝐆𝐗\tilde{\mathbf{Y}}=\mathbf{G}\mathbf{X}. Then we have,

I​(𝐗;𝐘~|𝐆)=I​(𝐗;𝐘~)+I​(𝐗;𝐆|𝐘~)𝐼𝐗conditional~𝐘𝐆𝐼𝐗~𝐘𝐼𝐗conditional𝐆~𝐘I(\mathbf{X};\tilde{\mathbf{Y}}|\mathbf{G})=I(\mathbf{X};\tilde{\mathbf{Y}})+I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{G}|\tilde{\mathbf{Y}})

Now note that 1n​I​(𝐗;𝐘~)=o​(1)1𝑛𝐼𝐗~𝐘𝑜1\frac{1}{n}I(\mathbf{X};\tilde{\mathbf{Y}})=o(1). Then we need to evaluate I​(𝐆;𝐗|𝐘~)≤H​(𝐆)−H​(𝐆|𝐘~,𝐗)𝐼𝐆conditional𝐗~𝐘𝐻𝐆𝐻conditional𝐆~𝐘𝐗I(\mathbf{G};\mathbf{X}|\tilde{\mathbf{Y}})\leq H(\mathbf{G})-H(\mathbf{G}|\tilde{\mathbf{Y}},\mathbf{X}). Now note that since each row of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} is an independent Bernoulli∼βsimilar-toabsent𝛽\sim\beta sequence we can split the entropy into sum of entropies each individual rows. To this end focus on the first row. Then conditioned on there being l𝑙l 111’s in the row we have,

H​(𝐆1|l)≤(nl)𝐻conditionalsubscript𝐆1𝑙binomial𝑛𝑙H(\mathbf{G}_{1}|l)\leq\binom{n}{l}. Given that X𝑋X is k𝑘k-sparse we have,

H​(𝐆1|𝐗,𝐘~,l,k)=∑j=0min⁡(k,l)(kj)​(n−kl−j)(nl)​log⁡(kj)​(n−kl−j)𝐻conditionalsubscript𝐆1𝐗~𝐘𝑙𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑘𝑙binomial𝑘𝑗binomial𝑛𝑘𝑙𝑗binomial𝑛𝑙binomial𝑘𝑗binomial𝑛𝑘𝑙𝑗H(\mathbf{G}_{1}|\mathbf{X},\tilde{\mathbf{Y}},l,k)=\sum_{j=0}^{\min(k,l)}\dfrac{\binom{k}{j}\binom{n-k}{l-j}}{\binom{n}{l}}\log\binom{k}{j}\binom{n-k}{l-j}

Thus we have

I​(𝐗;𝐆|𝐘~,k,l)≤(nl)−∑j=0min⁡(k,l)(kj)​(n−kl−j)(nl)​log⁡(kj)​(n−kl−j)=H​(J|k,l)𝐼𝐗conditional𝐆~𝐘𝑘𝑙binomial𝑛𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑘𝑙binomial𝑘𝑗binomial𝑛𝑘𝑙𝑗binomial𝑛𝑙binomial𝑘𝑗binomial𝑛𝑘𝑙𝑗𝐻conditional𝐽𝑘𝑙I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{G}|\tilde{\mathbf{Y}},k,l)\leq\binom{n}{l}-\sum_{j=0}^{\min(k,l)}\dfrac{\binom{k}{j}\binom{n-k}{l-j}}{\binom{n}{l}}\log\binom{k}{j}\binom{n-k}{l-j}=H(J|k,l)

where J𝐽J is a random variable with distribution given by,

P​r​(J=j)=(kj)​(n−kl−j)(nl)𝑃𝑟𝐽𝑗binomial𝑘𝑗binomial𝑛𝑘𝑙𝑗binomial𝑛𝑙Pr(J=j)=\dfrac{\binom{k}{j}\binom{n-k}{l-j}}{\binom{n}{l}}

For large enough n𝑛n, k=α​n𝑘𝛼𝑛k=\alpha n and l=β​n𝑙𝛽𝑛l=\beta n w.h.p. Thus I​(𝐗;𝐆|𝐘)≤H​(J~)𝐼𝐗conditional𝐆𝐘𝐻~𝐽I(\mathbf{X};\mathbf{G}|\mathbf{Y})\leq H(\tilde{J}), where J~~𝐽\tilde{J} has a limiting distribution given by,

P​r​(J~=j)=(α​nj)​(n​(1−α)β​n−j)(nβ​n)𝑃𝑟~𝐽𝑗binomial𝛼𝑛𝑗binomial𝑛1𝛼𝛽𝑛𝑗binomial𝑛𝛽𝑛Pr(\tilde{J}=j)=\dfrac{\binom{\alpha n}{j}\binom{n(1-\alpha)}{\beta n-j}}{\binom{n}{\beta n}}

In other words given ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 there exists an n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} such that for all n≥n0𝑛subscript𝑛0n\geq n_{0}, sup𝑗​|PJ​(j)−PJ~​(j)|≤ϵ𝑗supremumsubscript𝑃𝐽𝑗subscript𝑃~𝐽𝑗italic-ϵ\underset{j}{\sup}|P_{J}(j)-P_{\tilde{J}}(j)|\leq\epsilon and by continuity of the entropy function, [[16], pp. 33, Lemma 2.7], it follows that |H​(J)−H​(J~)|≤−ϵ​log⁡ϵn𝐻𝐽𝐻~𝐽italic-ϵitalic-ϵ𝑛|H(J)-H(\tilde{J})|\leq-\epsilon\log\dfrac{\epsilon}{n}

XII-B Contiguous sampling

In this case for each row we have H​(𝐆1)=log⁡n𝐻subscript𝐆1𝑛H(\mathbf{G}_{1})=\log n. To evaluate H​(𝐆1|𝐗,𝐘~)𝐻conditionalsubscript𝐆1𝐗~𝐘H(\mathbf{G}_{1}|\mathbf{X},\tilde{\mathbf{Y}}), fix the number of ones in 𝐆1subscript𝐆1\mathbf{G}_{1} to be equal to l𝑙l and the number of non-zero elements in 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} to be equal to k𝑘k. Now note that if Y~1=0subscript~𝑌10\tilde{Y}_{1}=0 then there is no overlap in 𝐆1subscript𝐆1\mathbf{G}_{1} and 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}. This means that the row of 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} can have contiguous ones in n−k−l𝑛𝑘𝑙n-k-l positions equally likely. The probability of no overlap is n−k−ln𝑛𝑘𝑙𝑛\frac{n-k-l}{n}. On the other hand if Y~1>0subscript~𝑌10\tilde{Y}_{1}>0, then uncertainty in locations of ones in 𝐆1subscript𝐆1\mathbf{G}_{1} reduces to log⁡(k+l)𝑘𝑙\log(k+l). The probability that Y>0𝑌0Y>0 is k+ln𝑘𝑙𝑛\frac{k+l}{n}. Thus we have,

I​(𝐆1;𝐗|𝐘~)≤m​H​(O)𝐼subscript𝐆1conditional𝐗~𝐘𝑚𝐻𝑂I(\mathbf{G}_{1};\mathbf{X}|\tilde{\mathbf{Y}})\leq mH(O)

where O𝑂O is a binary random variable with distribution (1−k+ln),k+ln1𝑘𝑙𝑛𝑘𝑙𝑛(1-\frac{k+l}{n}),\frac{k+l}{n}. For large enough n𝑛n this comes close to 1−(α+β),α+β1𝛼𝛽𝛼𝛽1-(\alpha+\beta),\alpha+\beta. Thus we have,

I​(𝐆;𝐗|𝐘)≤m​H​(α+β)𝐼𝐆conditional𝐗𝐘𝑚𝐻𝛼𝛽I(\mathbf{G};\mathbf{X}|\mathbf{Y})\leq mH(\alpha+\beta)
